169
 
CHAPTER 169
Affirmative Action
169.01   Definitions.
169.02    Equal employment opportunity clause.
169.03    Affirmative Action Officer.
169.04    Contract compliance requirements; construction contracts.
169.05    Supplies.
169.06    Contract disposition.
169.07    Emergency employment.
169.08    Plan of action.
169.09    Executive responsibility.
169.10    Dissemination of policy and program.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Unlawful discriminatory practices - see Ohio R.C. 4112.02
Department of Community Development - see ADM. Ch.
167
Interfering; with civil rights - see GEN. OFF.
525.13
 
 
169.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed herein
unless otherwise provided:
   (a)    "Discriminate", "discriminates" and "discrimination" mean to
distinguish, differentiate, separate or segregate on the basis of race,
religion, color, sex or national origin.
   (b)    "Contractor" means any person, partnership, corporation, association
or joint venture which has been awarded a public contract and includes every
subcontractor on such contract.
   (c)    "Subcontractor" means any person, partnership, corporation,
association or joint venture which supplies any of the work, labor, services,
supplies, equipment, materials or any combination of the foregoing under a
contract with the contractor on a public contract.
   (d)    "Public contract" means any contract awarded by the City whereby the
City is committed to expend or does expend its funds in return for work, labor,
services, supplies, equipment, materials or any combination of the foregoing,
or any lease, lease by way of concession, concession agreement permit, property
of the City or otherwise grants a right or privilege to occupy or use property
of the City.
   (e)    "Bidder" means any person, partnership, corporation, association or
joint venture seeking to be awarded a public contract.
   (f)   "Construction contract" means any public contract for the
construction, rehabilitation, alteration, conversion, extension, wrecking,
excavation or repair of buildings, streets or other improvements to real
property.
      (Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.02 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY CLAUSE.
   (a)    All public contracts hereinafter entered into by the City shall
incorporate an equal employment opportunity clause to be approved by the City's
Affirmative Action Officer, so that equal opportunity for employees and
applicants for employment be offered to all persons without regard to race,
color, creed, national origin or sex.
   
   (b)    It will be the policy of the Local Public Agency to provide equal
opportunity in employment for all qualified persons, to prohibit discrimination
in employment because of race, color, creed, national origin or sex and to
promote equal employment through a positive continuing program for itself and
each of its contracting agents. This policy of equal employment opportunity
shall apply to every aspect of employment policies and practices in every
department of the City.
(Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.03 AFFIRMATIVE ACTION OFFICER.
   There is presently established in the Department of Community Development
the position of Affirmative Action Officer. The duties of the Affirmative
Action Officer are to administer and enforce the City's equal employment
opportunity commitments established by this chapter and the subsequent
procedures designed to effectuate this plan. Also, all determinations as to
compliance to this program shall be met by the contracting parties for such
purposes. The Affirmative Action Officer shall have the full cooperation to
secure pertinent information from all City departments, inclusive of the
Department of Community Development, and any independent agencies who may be
under contract with the City.
(Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.04 CONTRACT COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS; CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS.
   (a)    All notices to prospective bidders related to construction contracts
published on behalf of the City shall include as a part of the contract
specifications the condition that all bidders will be required to become
signatories to the Canton Hometown Bid Conditions.
   (b)    All reports required by the Affirmative Action Officer shall be
submitted in duplicate to the Department of Community Development office of the
affirmative action.
   (c)    Each bidder shall file as part of the bid documents, contract
employment reports with the City as may be directed by the Affirmative Action
Officer. Such contract employment reports shall include such information as
employment practices, policies, programs and statistics of the contractor and
shall be in such form as the Affirmative Action Officer may prescribe.
Subcontractors shall also submit such contract employment reports to the City
before approval by the City as a subcontractor. This policy is applicable to
all contracts, both federal and non-federal. (Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.05 SUPPLIES.
   Suppliers and non-construction contractors will be required to state whether
or not their company has an affirmative action program. In the event that such
program is found to exist, a copy, with documentation, will be submitted to the
Affirmative Action Officer for review. In the event that the company or
supplier has not prepared an affirmative action program, the "Employer's Manual
on Affirmative Action in employment" will be remitted to such company,
permitting them to develop an affirmative action program.
(Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.06 CONTRACT DISPOSITION.
   (a)    In the event a contractor fails to cooperate in reaching mutually
satisfactory solutions or to implement contract compliance agreements
previously made, the Affirmative Action Officer shall review such cases to
determine whether further efforts to reach alternative solutions are desirable.
Depending upon the nature of the problem, such alternatives may involve contact
with industry, related labor unions or requesting the assistance of the Ohio
Civil Rights Commission, the office of Federal Contract Compliance and/or the
particular federal agency involved.
   (b)    In the event the Affirmative Action Officer determines that the
contractor has violated or has failed to comply with the equal opportunity
requirements of the contract after affording such contractor a reasonable time
to correct his situation, and where negotiations have been of no avail, the
Affirmative Action Officer shall submit a written finding, and shall transmit
such finding and subsequent recommendations to the Mayor and the statutory
department directors. In the event that the violation cannot be resolved in the
Mayor's office, it will be forwarded to the proper federal agencies.
(Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.07 EMERGENCY EMPLOYMENT.
   (a)    The City, in order to meet all federal requirements will develop and
immediately implement recruitment programs in each department, designed to
insure that all departments have a minimum minority workforce equaling 9.3
percent. Whereas the 1970 census shows the minority workforce to be 9.3 percent
of the total workforce of the City, therefore, this shall be the base goal in
the implementation of the affirmative action program. A re-evaluation of
workforce statistics will be conducted in the final quarter of each calendar
year by the Affirmative Action Officer. This shall subsequently result in an
annually adjusted base, subject to Council approval, of employment goals for
the City, which reflects a more precise percentage of minorities who have
entered the Municipality's general workforce.
   (b)    Those City departments whose present workforce does not represent the
employee balance as annually determined by this chapter shall develop an
employment policy which will achieve the aforementioned annual goal, with the
assistance of the Affirmative Action Officer. (Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.08 PLAN OF ACTION.
   (a)    This affirmative action plan shall be communicated to all employees,
supervisors, management officials of the Local Public Agency and all
contracting groups working with the Local Public Agency.
   (b)   When it is necessary to recruit applicants for employment, the Local
Public Agency shall:
      (1)    Place employment advertisements in newspapers, which reach the
largest number of minority group people in the area and in such advertisements,
identify itself as an equal opportunity employer;
      (2)    Notify the office of affirmative action, Affirmative Action
Officer, schools and colleges having a substantial number of minority students;
      (3)    Be responsible for maintaining contact with minority relations
organizations to encourage referral of qualified minority applicants to
employers;
      (4)    Encourage referral of minority applicants by present employees;
and
      (5)    Incorporate and use appropriate guidelines of the acts and orders
provided herein.
   (c)    In-plant and on-the-job training programs, as well as other
educational or training programs to which the Local Public Agency gives support
or can obtain support, will be reviewed regularly to assure that minority group
candidates are treated equally in the arraignment of available jobs.
   (d)    The Department of Community Development will maintain a minority job
bank. This job bank will consist of a listing of skilled and unskilled
minorities seeking employment.
   (e)    Qualified minority employees will be paid the same rates as other
employees with equivalent duties and will be given the same opportunities for
overtime work.
   (f)   Layoffs, demotions or terminations will be on a nondiscriminatory
basis with each layoff, demotion or termination of a minority worker reviewed
by the company's Affirmative Action Officer or official assigned to oversee the
equal employment opportunity program.
   (g)    The Local Public Agency will encourage minority group contractors,
minority group subcontractors and firms with minority representation to bid for
subcontracting and contracting work.
   (h)    The office of affirmative action and the Affirmative Action Officer
shall make periodic reports of its progress under this plan giving any
statistical data required and shall make copies of such reports available to
the required federal and local agencies.
(Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.09 EXECUTIVE RESPONSIBILITY.
   The head of each department agency with the assistance of the Affirmative
Action Officer will develop and initiate an immediate recruitment program to
increase the number of minorities in their various departments to a level that
equals or surpasses the percentage of minorities in the total City workforce.
The responsibility for implementation of these programs shall lie with the
Mayor, respective department directors, Civil Service Commissioners, union
representatives and shall be co-ordinated by the Affirmative Action Officer.
(Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
169.10 DISSEMINATION OF POLICY AND PROGRAM.
   (a)    Procedure.
      (1)    All personnel grievances involving alleged violations of anti-
discrimination policies, in relation to hiring and recruitment or treatment of
presently employed persons within the City government will be investigated by
the Affirmative Action Officer. He will submit all findings and recommendations
to the Mayor, the statutory department head involved and the aggrieved
applicant. In the event that the applicant or employee is not satisfied, the
Affirmative Action Officer will advise him or her of his or her right to
appeal. Further, the Affirmative Action Officer will educate the applicants as
to the procedures of appeal and will provide whatever information is requested
as relates to such appeal.
      (2)    All personnel grievances involving alleged violations of anti-
discrimination policies in relation to hiring and recruitment or treatment of
presently employed persons by an employer who has a contract with the City,
that does not involve federal funds will be investigated by the Affirmative
Action Officer. The Affirmative Action Officer will submit findings and
recommendations to the Mayor, the Director of Public Safety and Service and the
accused employer. In the event that no discrimination is found to exist, the
case will be closed as far as the City government is concerned. Appeal rights
are the same as in subsection (a)(l) hereof. In the event that the employer is
found to be in violation, he will be asked to remedy the situation. If the
employer continues in violation, then he will not be considered for any further
contracts with the City until the violation is remedied.
      (3)    Any violation of nondiscrimination policies on a federally funded
project will be investigated by the Affirmative Action Officer. He will present
his findings and recommendations to the Mayor and the Director of Public Safety
and Service for resolution. In the event that the violation cannot be resolved
by the City government, proceedings to show cause will be initiated with the
proper federal agency, as provided for by Executive Ordinance 11246.
   (b)    Records.
      (1)    All grievances will be submitted in writing and be notarized.
      (2)    All telephone or other conversations relating to the grievance
will be documented for further reference.
      (3)    Files and reports shall be maintained of the type of action taken
to resolve the employee’s or applicant's grievance.
         (Ord. 9-75. Passed 1-20-75.)
CHAPTER 171
Litter Control Board
171.01     Creation.
171.02 Purpose.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Removal of litter - see Ohio R.C. 731.51 et seq.
Litter control - see Ohio R.C. 1502
Littering prohibited - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
 
 
171.01 CREATION.
   There is hereby created the Alliance Litter Control Advisory Board,
consisting of five members who shall serve without compensation, to be
appointed by the Mayor with the consent of Council and who shall serve at the
pleasure of the Mayor. The Board shall have the following minimum
representation:
(a)    One local government official;
(b)    One law enforcement official;
(c)    One public education official;
   (d)    Two other public members.
      (Ord. 92-82. Passed 8-2-82. )
171.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Alliance Litter Control Advisory Board is to advise in
the development and implementation of the local litter control program and with
the approval of the local government shall:
   (a)    Provide recommendations and direction to the local government in
developing program goals and objectives;
   (b)    Make recommendations concerning the selection of the program manager;
   (c)    Advise the local government concerning the implementation of the
program;
   (d)    Provide an opportunity for public input into the grant application
and program development process; and
   (e)    Carry out any further responsibilities as required by the Office of
Litter Control of the State of Ohio.
      (Ord. 92-82. Passed 8-2-82.)
CHAPTER 173
Handicapped Discrimination Review Board
173.01    Members; authority; meetings.
173.02    Grievances.
 
 
173.01 MEMBERS; AUTHORITY; MEETINGS.
   (a)    There is hereby created a Handicapped Discrimination Review Board
which shall be composed of three electors of the City appointed by the Mayor.
   (b)    The Board shall have the authority to adopt rules and regulations to
govern its operation and procedure which are not inconsistent with acts of
Council or any other legislative agency.
   (c)    The Board shall meet on a monthly basis and at such other times as it
may determine are necessary to effectuate its purpose.
(Ord. 88-84. Passed 10-15-84.)
173.02 GRIEVANCES.
   (a)    A grievance may be filed with the Board by filing a written statement
of the grievance with the City Auditor. The Auditor shall, within five days of
the receipt of any such grievances file with the responsible employee, as
designated by the Mayor, and provide to the members of the Board, copies of any
such grievance.
   (b)    The Board shall meet to review and resolve any such grievance within
thirty days of the date of filing of the same:
      (1)    The Board shall first determine if it has jurisdiction over the
subject matter of the grievance.
      (2)    The Board, if it finds jurisdiction, may fashion a remedy which it
shall recommend, in writing to the Mayor within the thirty-day review period.
      (3)    It shall further provide copies of any such recommendation to the
Auditor, Safety-Service Director, responsible employee and Council for such
action as the City shall deem necessary and advisable.
   (c)    The Board shall have jurisdiction only in those claims arising from
the ownership, operation or control of any land or buildings by the City or any
of its various other boards, commissions, agencies or other official
instrumentalities.
(Ord. 88-84. Passed 10-15-84.)
CHAPTER 175
Keep America Beautiful Commission
175.01    Purpose; members.
175.02    Secretary.
175.03   Meetings; record.
175.04    Authority; funds.
 
 
175.01 PURPOSE; MEMBERS.
   (a)    There shall be a Keep America Beautiful Commission in the City. The
Commission shall advise Council and carry out Council’s directives in matters
relating to refuse and environmental management.
   (b)   The Keep America Beautiful Commission shall consist of nine members
who shall be residents of the greater Alliance area. The members shall be
nominated by the Mayor and approved by Council. The members shall be nominated
from the following groups if possible:
 
   Group                         Number
   Business, industry, or professional              1
   Labor                          1
   Community Service Organization              1
   Education                       1
   Youth Service Organization                 1
   Members at Large                    4
   The term of office for each Commissioner shall be two years coinciding with
the terms of City Council. In the event that a vacancy occurs prior to the
expiration a Commissioner’s term the Mayor with the approval of City Council
shall appoint a successor Commissioner to fulfill the unexpired term. The
Director of Public Safety and Service or designee shall serve as a permanent,
non-voting ex-officio member of the Commission
(Ord. 53-22. Passed 8-15-22.)
175.02 SECRETARY.
   The Executive Director of the Keep America Beautiful Commission shall be the
nonvoting secretary of the Commission. He shall be custodian of all minutes and
records of the Commission and shall perform such other duties on behalf of the
Commission as it may deem desirable to carry out its duties as set forth
herein. The Executive Director shall be appointed by the Mayor. The Executive
Director shall report and be responsible to the Mayor for the purpose of
implementing the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 60-85. Passed 6-3-85.)
175.03 MEETINGS; RECORD.
   The Commission shall meet not less than four (4) times per year. The members
of the Commission shall regularly attend meetings and public hearings of the
Commission. Members shall serve without compensation except for reimbursement
of authorized expenses attendant to the performance of their duties. The
Commission shall have the power to adopt rules and regulations for its
operation. The Commission shall hold an organization meeting in January of each
even-numbered year and shall elect a Chairperson, Vice-Chairperson and
Secretary from among the voting members before proceeding to any other
business. The Commission shall keep a record of proceedings. Newly appointed
members shall be installed at the first regular meeting after their
appointment.
   The Executive Director shall submit a report to Council after each regular
meeting of the Commission, showing the cumulative attendance of each member,
with notation of members who have been absent from three (3) consecutive
meetings.
(Ord. 74-19. Passed 11-18-19.)
175.04 AUTHORITY; FUNDS.
   (a)    The Keep America Beautiful Commission shall recommend refuse and
environmental management policies to Council. The Commission shall have the
following goals:
      (1)    Develop and recommend for adoption refuse and environmental policy
plan(s); including alternatives and enforcement;
      (2)    Review actions of the City relevant to any such policy;
      (3)    Develop and recommend management and program priorities;
      (4)    Monitor City performance and make an annual report to Council; and
      (5)    Carry out such other tasks as Council may designate.
   (b)    The Commission may expend any funds that may from time to time be
allocated by Council. The City may receive donations from the general public,
business, industry, foundations and other sources for the purposes embraced by
the Commission's purpose and goals. Such donations may be used solely for the
payment of Commission expenses or any salary set by Council for the Executive
Director.
(Ord. 60-85. Passed 6-3-85.)
CHAPTER 176
   Downtown Special Events Commission
176.01   Established.
176.02   Purpose.
176.03   Duties.
176.04   Composition.
176.05   Term of office.
176.06   Officers.
176.07   Meetings.
176.08   Powers.
176.09   Fund raising activities.
176.10   Accounting of moneys.
176.11   Reports.
176.12   Rules and procedures.
176.13   Attendance policy; vacancies.
 
 
176.01 ESTABLISHED.
   Council hereby creates the Downtown Special Events Commission.
(Ord. 138-07. Passed 12-17-07.)
176.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this Commission shall be to plan and implement special events
programs for the downtown area, such as musical concerts, car shows and
“cruise-ins”, summer festivals and other similar activities.
(Ord. 138-07. Passed 12-17-07.)
176.03 DUTIES.
   When requested by Council, the Commission shall give advice and assistance
on matters concerning downtown special events.
(Ord. 138-07. Passed 12-17-07.)
176.04 COMPOSITION.
   The Commission shall be comprised of up to eleven members known as
“Commissioners”, appointed by the Mayor with the approval of Council. The
members shall be “members at large” and be individuals who have demonstrated an
interest in working for the improvement of the downtown area of Alliance, Ohio.
Commissioners shall be residents of Butler, Marlboro, Paris, Lexington or
Washington Townships. (Ord. 2-16. Passed 1-4-16.)
176.05 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   The term of office for each Commissioner shall be three years with the terms
of office staggered each calendar year. In the event that a vacancy occurs
prior to the expiration of a Commissioner’s term, the Mayor with the approval
of Council shall appoint a successor Commissioner to fulfill the unexpired
term. The Mayor may reappoint the Commissioner or cause the appointment of a
new Commissioner to the Downtown Special Events Commission.
(Ord. 2-16. Passed 1-4-16.)
176.06 OFFICERS.
   (a)   The Commission shall elect from its membership a chairperson, vice-
chairperson and secretary.
(Ord. 138-07. Passed 12-17-07.)
   (b)   The Chairperson shall be responsible for insuring all facilities are
properly prepared and available for all downtown events. (Ord. 2-16. Passed 1-
4-16.)
176.07 MEETINGS.
   The Commission shall hold meetings whenever it deems necessary, but no less
than quarterly at locations in the City of Alliance or any other location the
Commission deems necessary for investigative purposes, at times it may
designate. All meetings of the Commission shall be in accordance with the Ohio
open meetings laws. The presence of a majority of the Commissioners then in
office shall be necessary and sufficient to constitute a quorum, and an
affirmative of the majority of those commissioners present shall be necessary
to pass upon pending questions, except that on tie votes, the vote of the
chairman shall be determinative. Minutes of the meeting shall be kept and the
records filed with the person performing the duty of the custodian of the
records of the Council. (Ord. 2-16. Passed 1-4-16.)
176.08 POWERS.
   In the performance of its functions, the Commission is empowered to
research, plan and implement special events programs in the downtown area,
examples of said functions may include, but are not limited to:
   (a)   Obtaining necessary event permits (excluding liquor permits);
   (b)   Contracting entertainment;
   (c)   Soliciting food vendors and other vendors;
   (d)   Coordinating with City Government to close certain streets during
events;
   (e)   Coordinating with downtown local businesses;
   (f)   Researching, planning and implementing methods by which special event
programs can be self funded;
   (g)   Fund raising activities.
      (Ord. 18-08. Passed 3-3-08.)
176.09 FUND RAISING ACTIVITIES.
   The Downtown Special Events Commission shall commence with fund raising
activities to solicit donations and contributions in order to provide for
downtown special events without the necessity of spending tax dollars for
social events during the troubled economic times facing the Alliance City
residents. (Ord. 18-08. Passed 3-3-08.)
176.10 ACCOUNTING OF MONIES.
   The Auditor of the City of Alliance is authorized and directed to establish
Downtown Special Events Revenue-Donations Code No. 269-0-120-41119 and Downtown
Special Events Expenditure Code No. 269-3-401-53133 for the purpose of
receiving donations and contributions and providing for the necessary
expenditures from said codes for the Downtown Special Events Committee. All
monies raised, contributed or donated to the Downtown Special Events Committee
shall be maintained with strict governmental accountability and subject to
audit by the Alliance City Auditor’s Office and State Auditor.
(Ord. 18-08. Passed 3-3-08.)
176.11 REPORTS.
   From time to time, at the request of Council and/or the Mayor, the
Commission shall submit to Council a written report of its activities and plans
of which these documents shall be retained as part of the official City
records. Subject to the approval of the Mayor and/or Director of Public Safety
and Service, the facilities and personnel of the City shall be made available
to assist the Commission in carrying out its functions.
(Ord. 138-07. Passed 12-17-07.)
176.12 RULES AND PROCEDURES.
   The Commission is authorized to amend its rule and procedures for the
conduct of its authorized activities subject to the approval of Council.
(Ord. 138-07. Passed 12-17-07.)
176.13 ATTENDANCE POLICY; VACANCIES.
   The Commission members are subject to the attendance policy and procedure
hereby adopted by Council and any member who misses three consecutive meetings
or Commission events, or whose overall attendance at regular meetings or
Commission events for any twelve month period falls below seventy-five percent
(75%) has automatically vacated his/her seat. The Commission shall at once
notify the Council that a vacancy exists. (Ord. 2-16. Passed 1-4-16.)
CHAPTER 177
Economic Development Program
177.01    Fund created.
177.02    Project Screening Committee.
177.03    Program administration.
177.04    Program guidelines.
177.05    Application procedure.
177.06    Loan agreement negotiations.
177.07    Awarding loan.
177.08    Program administrator responsible.
177.09    City administrative cost reimbursement.
177.10    Amendment.
177.11   Information to members of City Council.
 
 
177.01 FUND CREATED.
   There is hereby created an Alliance U.D.A.G. Fund and an Economic
Development Revolving Loan Fund Account (RLF). The RLF Account will be funded
by the repayment of existing H.U.D.-U.D.A.G. (Urban Development Action Grant)
loans. All monies received by the City as and for repayment of existing or
future U.D.A.G. loans (development loans made by or through the City using the
proceeds of U.D.A.G to the City), will be deposited into the RLF and used
thereafter solely in accordance with the guidelines established herein.
Additional funds may be generated by future economic development activities or
such other sources as Council may from time to time specify.
(Ord. 10-88. Passed 2-16-88.)
177.02 PROJECT SCREENING COMMITTEE.
   There is hereby created an Economic Development Project Screening Committee
(EDPSC) composed of seven members with business/finance backgrounds, including,
but not limited to representatives of local financial institutions, the Stark
Development Board, the Greater Alliance Development Corporation, and the
Alliance Chamber of Commerce. The members shall be appointed by the Mayor, with
the consent and approval of Council, to serve for a term of three years, except
that originally three members shall be appointed for three years, two members
for two years and two members for one year. The EDPSC shall meet as needed to
review loan applications and recommendations received from the Program
Administrator. It shall adopt such rules, regulations and procedures for its
own conduct and operation as shall be reasonably necessary and proper to carry
out its function under this chapter. The EDPSC shall recommend to Council those
loans or other economic development activities which the EDPSC has determined
should be approved for funding from the RLF. In considering loans or other
economic development activities the EDPSC shall consider each of the program
guidelines set forth herein. Notwithstanding any delegation of authority to the
EDPSC and the Program Administrator, Council retains to itself absolute and
final authority to authorize or not authorize any economic loan or development
activity, or any part thereof, that is recommended by the EDPSC or Program
Administrator, and no disbursements shall be made from the RLF without the
express approval of Council.
(Ord. 85-10-S. Passed 10-17-11.)
177.03 PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION.
   The RLF will be administered through the Stark Development Board Finance
Corporation (SDB), or such other suitable agent or agency as City Council may
from time to time designate. This agent shall be known as the Program
Administrator, and shall serve for such terms and for such compensation or fees
as the City shall determine, such compensation or fees to be paid either by the
applicant or by the City. Any fees paid by the City shall be paid from the RLF.
The Program Administrator shall:
(a)    Prepare loan applications and provide the same for distribution through
City officials, the Alliance Chamber of Commerce, the Greater Alliance
Development Corporation, Stark Development Board or other.
(b)    Accept and review RLF loan applications and assist applicants in
preparing the same.
   (c)   As soon as is practical, make a written recommendation of approval or
disapproval on each application reviewed by it to the EDPSC.
(d)    Collect an application fee from the applicant for each loan application
received by it prior to reviewing the same.
(e)    Negotiate specific terms of financing plans with applicant and, if
applicable, with other funding sources such as S.B.A., Ohio Department of
Development, S.D.B., and the like.
(f)    Assist the applicant in the preparation of adequate business plans, and
if a loan is made, provide follow up assistance and training as necessary.
(g)    Prepare, subject to the Law Director's approval, all loan documentation
such as loan agreements, notes, mortgages, security agreements, guaranties and
the like.
(h)    Receive and collect all payments made by loan recipients, and account
for the same. Monies received by the Program Administrator shall be promptly
remitted to the City RLF.
(i)    Provide, no less often than quarterly, reports of its receipts and
collections to the City.
(j)    Report in writing to Council, no less often than semi-annually,
regarding its activities, the status of the existing and outstanding loans, the
activities of loan recipients and the status of efforts aimed at achieving the
goal set forth in Section
177.04(j).
    (k)   Projects totaling fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) or less which are
located in the Downtown Development District and which are secured by a first
priority mortgage, with a supporting independent appraisal, performed by a
licensed appraiser shall be submitted directly to the EDPSC for direct
recommendation to Council. (Ord. 85-10-S. Passed 10-17-11.)
177.04 PROGRAM GUIDELINES.
   In determining whether or not to recommend an application for approval, the
EDPSC shall consider the following guidelines as to each such application:
(a)    Job Creation. The number of jobs for City residents that will be created
by use of RLF funds. At least fifty-one percent (51%) of jobs created must be
for low or moderate income individuals. Job retention projects may be
considered under these same guidelines if the jobs retained can be verified as
jobs that will be (not may be or could be) lost.
   (b)    Underlying Private Financial Commitment. At least a 1:1 ratio of
private financial commitment to RLF funds is desirable. Higher ratios of
private financial commitment should receive higher competitive ratings in the
application review process. The private financial commitment shall not include
CDBG, SBA, EDA, or other public dollars that are involved in the project.
   (c)    Eligible Economic Development. The following economic development
activities, although not in order of priority, should be given priority over
other types of eligible economic development activities:
      (1)   Fixed asset capital expenditures (land, buildings, equipment or
other construction based elements); and
      (2)   Direct relocation costs and expenses incurred by companies
relocating businesses into the City of Alliance; and
      (3)   Expenses incurred in updating building codes, health codes, fire
codes and other code compliance in existing buildings located in the City of
Alliance; and
      (4)   Land acquisition, including land acquisition by the City directly,
or assistance to the loan applicant, or working in conjunction with the Greater
Alliance Development Corporation as the City’s Community Improvement
Corporation.
      (5)   Economic development activities in the area designated as the
Downtown Development District.
      No RLF loan funds shall be used to provide for inventory, refinancing or
wages.
   (d)    Equity and Collateral. All economic development projects shall
include a minimum of 10% developer equity, which shall be available and spent
before RLF loan funds may be spent. Acceptable collateral, including but not
limited to a mortgage, lien or UCC filing, should also be provided for at least
the full amount of the RLF loan funds involved in the project. Economic
development activities located in the Downtown Development District shall
provide collateral in the form of a mortgage or lien. For any loan in excess of
50% of the eligible economic development activities described in subsection (c)
hereof, the City may require that the City hold a mortgage and be in the first
position.
(e)    Firm Private Financial Commitments. All private financial commitments
must be finalized in written form. However, such commitments may be contingent
upon City approval of an RLF loan.
(f)    Documented Need. The project application must provide documentation on
the need for the RLF loan and that the request is not just a substitute for
private funds.
(g)    Location. Any projects recommended for funding must be located within
the corporate limits of the City of Alliance. Projects located outside of the
City limits may be considered. Any project funded by an RLF loan will be
required to remain in the City unless otherwise authorized by Council.
Relocation outside the City not otherwise authorized will result in
acceleration of the RLF loan balance.
   (h)    Downtown Development District. For projects located in the Downtown
Development District, loans may be made for up to 90% of the eligible economic
development activities described in subsection (c) hereof, subject to the
provisions of Section
177.06. The Downtown Development District shall include the area of the City of
Alliance with a zoning classification of B-1 and the Arch Avenue corridor with
a B-4 zoning classification.
      EDITOR’S NOTE: The Alliance Arts, Culture and Entertainment District was
also created to coincide with the boundaries of the Downtown Development
District and to be eligible for the same benefits as that district.
   (i)   City Officials and Employees Excluded. No loan, grant or other
economic development assistance shall be provided under this program to any
elected official of the City, any employee of the City or any member of the
EDPSC or to any corporation or partnership or other entity or business owned or
controlled by any of the foregoing, or to or by any member of the immediate
family of any of the foregoing. No loan, grant or other economic development
assistance shall be given to any corporation, partnership or other entity or
business in which any of the foregoing have any interest whatsoever unless
there shall be full, prior disclosure of such interest to City Council.
      (j)    In considering all loan applications and in making all
recommendations to Council, the EDPSC shall consider the City's goal that a
minimum of 10% of total loan funds per year be provided to minority applicants.
      (k)    Unless this section is waived by Council, applicants must attend
and complete a financial counseling session as directed by the Program
Administration.
      (l)    These guidelines shall not be deemed to be exclusive. Other
factors may also be considered by the EDPSC.
      (Ord. 85-10-S. Passed 10-17-11.)
177.05 APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   (a)    An application procedure will be established by the City requiring
application
submittals to include:
      (1)    A three-year proforma of income and expenses;
      (2)    Documentation of program compliance;
      (3)    Financial statements of all developers and tenants involved; and
      (4)    Letters of commitment on private financial sources, developer
intent and tenant commitment when appropriate.
   (b)    A nonrefundable application fee shall be paid by the applicant at the
time of the filing of the application. No application will be accepted without
the application fee.
(Ord. 22-08. Passed 7-21-08.)
177.06 LOAN AGREEMENT NEGOTIATIONS.
   The amount, rate and terms of loans will be negotiated by the Program
Administrator for the purpose of presenting a proposal for Council's
consideration. The rate of interest on any loan will be negotiated on a basis
of blending total interest involved in the project. The term of any loan will
be based on the collateral provided for the loan and generally will be no
longer than ten to twelve years for land and building and five to seven years
for equipment liens. The amount of any loan will generally be subject to:
   (a)   A minimum loan of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) except in cases
involving a project that creates more than two jobs and needs less than ten
thousand dollars ($10,000); and
      (b)    A maximum loan as may be determined by Council based upon the
available balance in the RLF and other factors deemed relevant by Council.
      (Ord. 85-10-S. Passed 10-17-11.)
177.07 AWARDING LOAN.
   The Program Administrator and the EDPSC will utilize the RLF Program
Guidelines and the financial soundness of each project as the basis for the
evaluation of projects. Council will ultimately determine the actual amount to
be loaned.
(Ord. 85-10-S. Passed 10-17-11.)
177.08 PROGRAM ADMINISTRATOR RESPONSIBLE.
   The Program Administrator shall be responsible for loan services, including
the execution of default and delinquent payment procedures as specified in the
RLF loan agreement. Loan repayments and interest will be managed by the Program
Administrator in accordance with its agreement with the City.
(Ord. 10-88. Passed 2-16-88.)
177.09 CITY ADMINISTRATIVE COST REIMBURSEMENT.
   The City proposes to recover some of its administrative costs in processing
loan application, loan agreements and managing the RLF account in the following
manner:
   (a)    The application fee shall be established as three hundred dollars
($300.00) per application. In the event that an independent appraiser is
necessary, the applicant shall also pay the cost of the independent appraisal.
Applicant shall be responsible for any closing costs charged by Stark
Development Board Loan Corporation, and any recording fees. (Ord. 22-08. Passed
7-21-08.)
   (b)    Additional administrative costs, if any, may be provided by the City
through the U.D.A.G. repayment funds annually in an amount not to exceed five
percent (5%) of the prior fiscal year's U.D.A.G. repayment receipts, from all
sources, subject to Council appropriations.
      (Ord. 10-88. Passed 2-16-88.)
177.10 AMENDMENT.
   This RLF plan and the RLF program guidelines may be amended as is prudent
and necessary. All proposed amendments shall be reviewed by the EDPSC and
forwarded with recommendations to Council for appropriate action.
(Ord. 10-88. Passed 2-16-88.)
177.11 INFORMATION TO MEMBERS OF CITY COUNCIL.
   The following information shall be provided to each member of City Council:
   (a)    The Director of Economic Development is authorized and directed to
notify members of Council of an application for a RLF loan at the next regular
meeting of Council following receipt of a RLF loan application. Such
notification to Council shall be conducted in executive session as permitted by
Ohio Revised Code section 122.22(E) and (G)(5) to ensure confidentiality of the
applicant and that of any proprietary information.
   (b)   The EDPSC shall provide a written report for each loan or other
economic development activity that the EDPSC recommends be approved or
disapproved for funding from the RLF. The report shall be provided not less
than 14 days before any vote by Council relating to the proposed loan. The
preliminary report as described in Section
177.11 (b) and delineated in conditions (l) through (6) listed below, shall be
conducted in executive session as provided by Ohio Revised Code section 121.22
(G)(5). and shall not constitute a public record pursuant to Ohio Revised Code
sections 149.43(A)(1)(v) and 1333.61. The report shall include, but not be
limited to, all the following:
      (1)   An analysis of each guideline set forth in Section
177.04.
      (2)   An explanation of each proposed deviation from the guidelines set
forth in Section
 177.04
      (3)   An explanation of any proposed deviation from the term guidelines
set forth in Section
 177.06.
      (4)   The current balance in the RLF before the proposed loan.
      (5)   The written report from the Program Administrator recommending
approval or disapproval, and
      (6)   The loan application.          
   (c)    The report described in Section
177.03(i).
   (d)   The report described in Section
177.03(j).
      (Ord. 85-10-S. Passed 10-17-11.)
CHAPTER 178
Commission on Citizen Relations
178.01   Establishment.
178.02   Composition; appointment.
178.03   Terms of members.
178.04   Organization.
178.05   Quorum.
178.06   Meeting; absence of member.
178.07   Duties; cooperation with City offices.
178.08   Prohibited practices.
178.09   Filing of complaints.
178.10   Investigation; determination.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Criminal activity nuisances - see BUS. REG.
734.05
 
178.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Commission on Citizen Relations.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.02 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT.
   The Commission on Citizen Relations shall consist of seven (7) members which
shall include the President of Council, the Law Director, the Chairman of the
Safety and Judiciary Committee of Council and four (4) other members to be
appointed by the Mayor with approval of the City Council. Members of the
Commission shall be chosen from among residents.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.03 TERMS OF MEMBERS.
   The term of office of each person appointed to the Commission on Citizen
Relations, unless otherwise expressly provided for by ordinance, is a term a
three (3) years with a maximum of three (3) consecutive terms, excluding those
who serve by reason of their office. Terms shall expire on the 31st day of
December.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.04 ORGANIZATION.
   The Commission on Citizen Relations shall elect from its members a
chairperson and such other positions as it deems necessary, and may adopt such
rules and regulations as may be necessary or appropriate to carry out its
responsibilities.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.05 QUORUM.
   The lesser of a majority of members or any four (4) members of the
Commission on Human Relations shall constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.06  MEETING; ABSENCE OF MEMBER.
   (a)   The Commission on Citizen Relations shall meet on call of the
chairperson or any three (3) members.
   (b)   Any member who is absent from three consecutive meetings in any twelve
consecutive months may be replaced as in the case of a vacancy.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.07 DUTIES; COOPERATION WITH CITY OFFICES.
   (a)   The Commission on Citizen Relations shall consult with the Mayor on
all matters involving racial, religious or ethnic prejudice or discrimination
and recommend such legislative or administrative action as it may deem
appropriate to effectuate the policy of this chapter. The Commission shall
render an annual report to the Mayor and City Council in January of each year.
   (b)   The Commission shall perform such further duties as may be delegated
to it by the Mayor and City Council.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.08 PROHIBITED PRACTICES.
   (a)   Discrimination, Generally. Every person shall be afforded the
opportunity to participate fully and equally in the public service offered by
the City without interference due to discrimination or prejudice by reason of
race, color, creed, class, national origin, religion, or sex. (Ord. 120-01.
Passed 11-19-01.)
178.09 FILING OF COMPLAINTS.
   (a)   Any person who believes that he or she has been aggrieved by an act or
omission which would constitute racial, religious, ethnic, class or sex
discrimination or prejudice with respect to a person or persons employed by the
City of Alliance may file a complaint with the Commission on Citizen Relations.
   (b)   The complainant shall make a written statement which details the
alleged unlawful practice, setting forth the facts upon which the complaint is
based and setting forth the facts sufficient to enable the Commission to
identify the City employee who is the subject of the complaint.
   (c)   All complaints shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the
occurrence of the alleged violation. Any complaint which is the subject of a
pending civil or criminal legal proceeding shall be immediately tabled until
the civil or criminal proceeding is concluded.
   (d)   No complaint will be received or acted upon by the Commission unless
it contains a statement that the alleged unlawful act was first presented to
the appropriate supervisor or department head and the decision of the
supervisor or department head shall be included in the complaint.
   (e)   Complaints filed may be voluntarily withdrawn at the request of the
complainant at any time prior to the completion of the Commission’s review.
(Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
178.10 INVESTIGATION; DETERMINATION.
   (a)   The Commission or its designee shall investigate allegations of
discrimination or prejudice set forth in any filed complaint in the manner it
deems most appropriate.
   (b)   If the Commission finds, with respect to any respondent, that the
Commission lacks jurisdiction or that the complaint is not supported by a
preponderance of the evidence, the Commission shall issue and cause to be
served on the appropriate parties an order dismissing the allegations of the
complaint.
   (c)   If the Commission determines that the complaint is supported by a
preponderance of the evidence, the matter shall be forwarded to the Mayor with
a recommendation for appropriate action. (Ord. 120-01. Passed 11-19-01.)
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial
Chap.
179. Municipal Court.
CHAPTER 179
Municipal Court
   EDITOR'S NOTE: There are no sections in Chapter
179. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references
and any future legislation. The Alliance Municipal Court having territorial
jurisdiction within the City and within Lexington, Marlboro, Paris and
Washington Townships, has been established under Ohio R.C. 1901.01 et seq. Ohio
R.C. 1901.25 provides that the Municipal Court may provide by rule how jurors
shall be chosen. Jurors' fees in any criminal case involving the violation of a
City ordinance shall be paid out of the City Treasury. The Municipal Court,
pursuant to Ohio R. C. 1901.26(A), may establish a schedule of fees and costs
to be taxed in any action or proceeding, whether civil or criminal. Ohio R.C.
1901.31(F) provides that fines received for violation of Alliance ordinances
shall be paid into the City Treasury. Rule 13 of the Ohio Traffic Rules as
promulgated by the Ohio Supreme Court provides that a court shall establish a
traffic violations bureau and specifies certain restrictions as to the
designated offenses and schedule of fines to be accepted as waiver payment in
lieu of court appearance.
CROSS REFERENCES

seq.

Bond for Court Clerk required - see Ohio R.C. 1901.31(D)

Record of traffic violations - see Ohio R.C. 4513.37
Law Director to be Prosecuting Attorney - see ADM.
137.01
Bond of Court employees - see ADM.
155.01
