725.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; SELLING UNLISTED GOODS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall offer for sale or sell any merchandise or articles not
listed on the inventory filed in the office of the Mayor as provided in Section
725.02 or hold any sale specified by this chapter without obtaining the license
required herein.
(1963 Code §725.01)
725.02 FILING INVENTORY; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   Every person, before conducting a fire sale, wreck sale, bankrupt sale,
closing-out sale, going-out-of-business sale or similar sale shall, no less
than seventy-two hours before the beginning thereof, file in the office of the
Mayor an inventory of any and all articles intended to be sold or offered for
sale at such sale. Such inventory shall contain or have attached thereto a
sworn statement that the articles contained on such inventory constitute the
actual stock in trade of the person at the premises where such person has been
doing business, that such articles have been owned by such person in doing
business at such location for at least one month immediately preceding such
sale, and that such articles were not acquired or brought to the location of
such sale especially or purposely for such sale. Upon filing of such verified
inventory and upon the Mayor's being satisfied that the sale is bona fide as
represented and the inventory filed is true and correct, the Mayor shall issue
a license for such sale.
(1963 Code §725.02)
725.03 LICENSE TIME LIMIT, REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION.
   A license issued as set out in Section
725.02 shall authorize the holding of such sale for a period of not to exceed
sixty days and shall not be renewable. A license issued hereunder may be
revoked or suspended by the Mayor upon proof of any violation of Sections
725.01 to
725.05 or for the conviction of the person holding such sale in violation of
any State or federal law or any ordinance of this City in connection with the
operation of such place of business, or upon proof of fraud in the operation of
the sale or for any misstatement in the affidavit or inventory filed. (1963
Code §725.03)
725.04  LICENSE FEE.
   Before issuing a license as required by Section
725.01, the Mayor shall receive from the person applying for such license
twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(1963 Code §725.04)
725.05  MISREPRESENTATION OF SALE.
   No person shall represent and advertise to the public by any means whatever
the holding of a fire sale, wreck sale, closing-out sale, going-out-of-business
sale, bankrupt sale or similar sale or make similar representations, unless
such representations and advertisements are in fact true and such sale is as
represented.
(1963 Code §725.05)
725.06 MISREPRESENTATION OF PRICE OR QUALITY.
   No person engaged in business in the City shall falsely represent by
advertisement or otherwise that goods, wares or merchandise which such person
offers for sale is of a certain brand or quality or that goods will be sold at
a certain percentage of their cost, price or value and then sell goods, wares
or merchandise of a brand or quality inferior to that represented or
advertised, nor sell such goods, wares or merchandise at a higher percent of
its cost value than represented or advertised.
(1963 Code §725.06)
725.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day on which sales are conducted in
violation of this chapter shall be held to constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 729
Coin-Operated Devices
729.01    Definitions.
729.02    License and registration required.
729.03    Application.
729.04    License issuance; registration sticker.
729.05    License fee, proration.
729.06    Expiration date.
729.07    Transfer of registration sticker.
729.08    Records of Mayor.
729.09    Obscene devices, peace disturbance prohibition.
729.10    Mayor to make rules and regulations.
729.11    Refusal to grant license; notice.
729.12    License revocation; notice.
729.13    Appeal.
729.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Music prohibited during certain hours - see GEN. OFF.
509.08
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
Using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
Amusements - see BUS. REG. Ch.
709
Pool rooms and bowling alleys - see BUS. REG. Ch.
745
 
 
729.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Mechanical amusement device" includes any machine or device which,
upon the insertion of a coin or token of any type in a slot or receptacle
attached to or in any way connected with such machine, operates or is designed
to operate as a game, contest or amusement, or which may be used for any such
game, contest or amusement.
   (b)    "Mechanical musical device" includes any machine, apparatus or device
designed or constructed for the purpose of producing, reproducing or playing
any musical or vocal tones or combination of tones, made possible by the
deposit or insertion of a coin or token of any kind in a slot or receptacle
attached to such machine or in connection therewith, which operates or is
designed to operate or which may be operated for such playing of music, tones
or combination of tones.
   The definitions contained in this section shall not be deemed to be
exclusive, and shall exclude and not be deemed to permit any device, the
possession of which is prohibited by law. (1963 Code § 729.01)
729.02  LICENSE AND REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person shall or shall be permitted to maintain, operate or have
possession of, in or about any premises under his control, which is open to the
public or to the membership of any club or society, any mechanical amusement
device or mechanical musical instrument or device, unless a license and
registration for each such device has first been obtained by the owner from the
Mayor.
   "Premises which are open to the public" or similar phrases, as used in this
section, shall include clubs, private clubs, headquarters and meeting places of
fraternal and other societies, associations, bodies and all other public
places.
(1963 Code §729.02)
729.03  APPLICATION.
   Application for the license required by Section
729.02 shall be made to the Mayor upon such forms as shall be prescribed
therefor. On such application, the applicant shall state his or its name,
whether an individual, partnership, corporation or other body, the address at
which it is desired to maintain and operate such device, the nature of the
business conducted at such place, the make, name, model, serial number and
other identifying information with reference to the particular device which it
is desired to operate, the name and address of the owner of such device and
such other and further information as the Mayor, in his exclusive discretion,
may require. (1963 Code §729.03)
729.04 LICENSE ISSUANCE; REGISTRATION STICKER.
   Upon the filing of the application and the payment of the fee required by
Section
729.05, the Mayor shall issue a license to such applicant. Such license shall
entitle the licensee to maintain and operate on the premises set forth and
described in the application, the device described in the application subject
to the terms and conditions of this chapter and of other provisions of these
Codified Ordinances applicable thereto, and also subject to such rules which
may be promulgated under Section
729.10.
   At the time of issuing such license, the Mayor shall also issue to the
licensee a registration slip or sticker for the device described in the
application.
(1963 Code §729.04)
729.05 LICENSE FEE, PRORATION.
   The annual fee for a license under this chapter shall be ten dollars
($10.00). In the event that a mechanical musical device or a mechanical
amusement device is installed on or subsequent to July 1 of any year, the
license fee therefor shall be five dollars ($5.00).
(Ord. 152-76. Passed 11-1-76.)
729.06  EXPIRATION DATE.
   All licenses required by this chapter shall expire on December 31 of the
year for which they were granted.   
(1963 Code §729.06)
729.07 TRANSFER OF REGISTRATION STICKER.
   Any licensee under the provisions of this chapter may transfer the
registration sticker issued in accordance with the provisions of Section
729.04, from time to time from one instrument or device to another, provided,
however, that application for such transfer shall be made to the Mayor and such
application shall be approved by the Mayor and a record thereof made in his
office. There shall be no fee for the transfer provided for in this section.
(1963 Code §729.07)
729.08 RECORDS OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall keep and maintain on file in his office a full and complete
list of all licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter together with
a cross index showing the location of each registered device.
(1963 Code §729. 08)
729.09  OBSCENE DEVICES, PEACE DISTURBANCE PROHIBITION.
   No person shall use or maintain any mechanical amusement device or
mechanical musical device which plays, produces, shows, displays or reproduces
any obscene, immoral or indecent selection, game or advertisement. No person
shall use, permit to be used or maintain any such device in any manner as to
disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood or of persons outside the
license premises.
(1963 Code §729.09)
729.10 MAYOR TO MAKE RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to establish, adopt and
enforce, or cause to be enforced, such rules and regulations concerning or
governing the issuance of licenses required under this chapter as he may deem
reasonable and necessary and which are not inconsistent with the provisions of
this chapter.
(1963 Code §729.10)
729.11 REFUSAL TO GRANT LICENSE; NOTICE.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to deny for a reasonable cause
any application for a license under this chapter. He shall notify such
prospective licensee by registered mail, directed to the last known address of
such prospective licensee, of his decision to deny such license.
(1963 Code §729.11)
729.12 LICENSE REVOCATION; NOTICE.
   The Mayor shall revoke the license of any licensee under this chapter who
violates any of the terms of this chapter or any of the rules and regulations
established and adopted by the Mayor pursuant to Section
729.10. The Mayor shall notify such licensee by registered mail, directed to
his last known address, of such revocation.
(1963 Code § 729.12)
729.13 APPEAL.
   Any licensee or prospective licensee under this chapter, whose license has
been revoked or who has been refused a license may appeal in writing to a board
consisting of the Mayor, the Director of Public Safety and Service and the
Police Chief, within ten days after the date of mailing of the notice or
revocation or denial by the Mayor. Such board shall consider such appeal in
whatever manner it may determine and its decision thereon shall be final.   
(1963 Code §729.13)
729.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   Any person so convicted shall not be eligible for another license under this
chapter for a period of six months from the date of revocation for such
offense.
(1963 Code §729.99)
CHAPTER 733
Dances and Dance Halls
733.01   Definitions.
733.02   License required; fee.
733.03   License duration.
733.04   Posting.
733.05   Issuance.
733.06   Forfeiture; issuance of new license.
733.07   Application investigation; inspection of premises.
733.08   Dance permit required; fee.
733.09   Permit application and form.
733.10   Sanitation and lighting.
733.11   Right of entry.
733.12   Minimum age.
733.13   Hours; exceptions.
733.14   Closing or vacating.
733.15   Inapplicable to private parties.
733.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate dancing academies or ballrooms - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
Permit required for public dancing - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
Intoxicating liquor in dance hall - see Ohio R.C. 4399.14
Disorderly conduct and peace disturbance - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
509
Liquor control - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
529
 
 
733.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, “public dance” or “public ball” means any dance or
ball to which admission can be had by payment of a fee or by the purchase,
possession or presentation of a ticket or token, or in which a charge is made
for caring for clothing or other property, or any other dance to which the
public generally may gain admission with or without the payment of a fee.
   “Public dance hall” means any room, place or space in which a public dance
or public ball is held. Any establishment open to the public in which food or
beverages of any kind are provided and wherein dancing is permitted shall be
deemed a public dance hall and the same shall constitute a public dance. (1963
Code §733.01)
733.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall hold any public dance or ball in any hall until the dance
hall in which the same may be held first has been licensed for such purposes.
Such license shall be issued by the Mayor. The fee for such license shall be
fifteen dollars ($15.00) and all moneys received by way of license fees shall
be paid into the General Fund of the City.
(1963 Code §733.02)
733.03 LICENSE DURATION.
   Each license granted under Section
733.02 shall expire on April 15 of each year.
(1963 Code §733.03)
733.04 POSTING.
   Every public hall shall post its license in a conspicuous place within the
hall where the dance is held. (1963 Code §733.04)
733.05 ISSUANCE.
   No license for a public dance hall shall be issued until it is found that
such hall complies with and conforms to all ordinances, health and fire
regulations of the City and the State, that it is properly ventilated and
supplied with sufficient toilet conveniences and that it is a safe and proper
place for the purpose for which it is to be used.
(1963 Code §733.05)
733.06 FORFEITURE; ISSUANCE OF NEW LICENSE.
   The license of any public dance hall may be forfeited or revoked by the
Mayor for disorderly or immoral conduct on the premises, or for the violation
of any of the rules, regulations, ordinances and laws governing or applying to
public dance halls or public dances. If at any time the license of a public
dance hall is forfeited or revoked, at least six months shall elapse before
another license or permit may be given for dancing on the same premises.
(1963 Code §733.06)
733.07 APPLICATION INVESTIGATION; INSPECTION OF PREMISES.
   The Director of Public Safety and Service shall examine all applications for
dance hall licenses and shall investigate each application to determine whether
or not the dance hall sought to be licensed complies with the applicable rules,
regulations, ordinances and laws of the Board of Health and the Fire Chief. The
Director of Public Safety and Service shall furnish the Mayor a reinspection of
the premises previous to granting the renewal license.
(1963 Code §733.07)
733.08 DANCE PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall hold a public dance or public ball within the limits of the
City without having first obtained a permit therefor from the Mayor. Such
permit may be issued by the Mayor upon the payment of a fee of two dollars
($2.00).
(1963 Code §733.08)
733.09 PERMIT APPLICATION AND FORM.
   The person desiring a permit to hold a public dance shall make application
to the Mayor in the following form:
 
The Mayor:
   Sir:
The undersigned, on behalf of                                    hereby makes application for a permit to give a public dance at
No.                             Street, on                    , 20     . It is hereby expressly agreed that such dance shall be
conducted in strict accord with the provisions of law regulating public dances and public halls, and the undersigned agrees that
the permit is given and accepted subject to the provisions of this application and that he shall be held responsible for any
violation of any provisions of law or ordinance regulating such public dance. The owner or lessee of the premises in which such
dance is to be held, is                         , No.                               Street (Avenue).
   Name                        Occupation                  Address                        
(1963 Code §733.09)
733.10 SANITATION AND LIGHTING.
   All public dance halls shall be kept in a clean, healthful and sanitary
condition at all times. All stairways and other passages and all rooms
connected with a public dance hall shall be kept open and well lighted.
(1963 Code §733.10)
733.11 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Director of Public Safety and Service, Police Chief or any other member
of the Police Department shall be permitted to have access to all public dance
halls, at all times, and to investigate complaints made with respect thereto.
(1963 Code §733.11)
733.12 MINIMUM AGE.
   It shall be unlawful after 9:00 p.m. to permit any person who has not
reached the age of eighteen years to attend or take part in any public dance,
unless such person be in company with a parent or guardian. No person shall
represent himself to have reached the age of eighteen years in order to obtain
admission to a public dance hall or to be permitted to remain therein when such
person is under eighteen years of age, and no person shall falsely represent
himself as a parent or guardian in order to obtain admission for a person who
is under the age of eighteen years.
(1963 Code §733.12)
733.13 HOURS; EXCEPTIONS.
   All public dances, except those conducted by bona fide night clubs, shall be
discontinued and all public dance halls shall be closed on or before the hour
of 12:00 midnight, provided, however, that upon the application of a bona fide
and responsible organization or society and upon an investigation by the
Director of Public Safety and Service, the Mayor may grant such organization or
society a permit to continue a dance until 2:00 a.m., but no ticket shall be
sold or accepted for admission after the hour of 12:00 midnight. Bona fide
night clubs shall be permitted to hold dances until 2:30 a.m.
(1963 Code §733.13)
733.14 CLOSING OR VACATING.
   The Director of Public Safety and Service, the Police Chief and members of
the Police Department shall have the power and it shall be their duty to cause
the place, hall or room where any dance or ball is held to be vacated whenever
any provisions of this chapter or any ordinance with regard to public dances
and public balls is being violated, whenever any indecent act is committed or
when any disorder of a gross, violent or vulgar character takes place therein.
(1963 Code §733.14)
733.15 INAPPLICABLE TO PRIVATE PARTIES.
   The provisions of this chapter shall in no way interfere with private
parties given in homes of people or with dances given by societies, clubs or
corporations where the attendance is restricted to the members of the society,
club or corporation.
(1963 Code §733.15)
733.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which an offense occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 734
Criminal Activity Nuisances
734.01   Definitions.
734.02   Finding of nuisance activities.
734.03   Costs.
734.04   Appeal.
734.05   Commission on Citizen Relations.
734.06   Other remedies.
734.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following activities occurring at a residential dwelling unit, and
engaged in by an owner, occupant or invitee of the owner or occupant of a
residential dwelling unit are hereby declared to be public nuisances:
   (a)   Any animal violations under Sections
505.01 (running at large),
505.09 (barking or howling dogs),
505.05 (killing or injuring animals), and
505.07,
505.071,
505.072 (cruelty to animals) of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes
of the State of Ohio;
   (b)    Any disorderly conduct, disturbance of the peace, noise or other
violation of Chapter
509 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (c)    Any drug abuse violation under Chapter
513 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio and
any felony violation under Ohio R.C. Chapter 2925;
   (d)    Any gambling violation under Chapter
517 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (e)    Any health, safety, or sanitation violation under Chapter
1721 of these Codified Ordinances, or Property Maintenance Code violations
under Chapter
1361 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (f)    Any obstruction of official business violation under Section
525.07 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (g)    Any alcohol violation under Chapter
529 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (h)    Any obscenity or sex offense under Chapter
533 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (i)    Any offense against another person under Chapter
537 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (j)    Any offense against property under Chapter
541 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (k)    Any weapons, explosives, firearm or handgun violation under Chapter
549 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (l)    Any fireworks violation under Section
549.11 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (m)    Any open burning or recreational fires in violation of Section
1511.05 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (n)    Any curfew violation under Section
509.10 of these Codified Ordinances and similar statutes of the State of Ohio;
   (o)   Any activity engaged in by a person less than 18 years of age which
would constitute a violation of an offense listed in this section if committed
by an adult.
      (Ord. 21-15. Passed 6-25-15.)
734.02 FINDING OF NUISANCE ACTIVITIES.
   (a)   The Chief of Police or his designee, upon finding that two nuisance
activities declared in Section
734.01 have occurred within any six-month period at a residential dwelling that
is leased by an owner to a tenant or tenants, shall, as a courtesy to the owner
of such property, attempt to cause a written notice of said nuisance activities
to be sent to the owner. However, failure to prove delivery of such notice
shall in no way prevent enforcement of any provision under this chapter. The
Chief of Police or his designee, upon finding that three or more nuisance
activities declared in Section
734.01 have occurred within any six-month period at a residential dwelling
unit, shall cause a written notice to be served on the owner of the property
declaring that such property is a nuisance property. The notice shall set forth
the nature of the nuisances, the estimated costs to respond to and abate a
similar future nuisance, and state that the owner may avoid being charged the
costs of response and abatement by taking steps to prevent any further nuisance
activities as set forth in this section. The notice shall further state that if
a fourth or subsequent nuisance activity as declared in Section
734.01 occurs within six months of the date of the notice, the city may abate
the nuisance by responding to the activities using administrative and law
enforcement actions, and the costs of such abatement shall be assessed on the
nuisance property. Notice shall be served on the owner personally or by
certified mail and regular mail to the person's residence, regular place of
business or last known address. If the certified or regular mail is returned
undelivered, a copy shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or on the
person's residence, regular place of business, last known address, or the
property affected.
   (b)   If within six months of the date of the notice referred to in
subsection (a) hereof, a fourth or subsequent nuisance activity as declared in
Section
734.01 occurs, the city may abate the nuisance by responding to the activities
using administrative and law enforcement action, and the costs of such
abatement shall be assessed on the nuisance property. The costs of such
response and abatement shall be calculated as set forth in Section
 734.03. Any further nuisance activity that occurs within six months of a
nuisance activity for which the owner has been given notice of assessment may
be charged to the owner.
(Ord. 21-15. Passed 6-25-15.)
734.03  COSTS.
   (a)   Cost of abatement shall be assessed per each nuisance in a six month
period and up to and including five nuisances by an assessment of a service fee
of $250.00 per each nuisance, by the Chief of Police or his or her designee.
Each nuisance in a six-month period in excess of five nuisances shall be
assessed a service fee of $500.00 by the Chief of Police or his or her
designee.
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall provide notice to the owner of the nuisance
property of the City's intent to assess the costs of responses and abatement
against the owner's property. Such notice shall contain a description of the
nuisance activity that is the basis for the notice of intent to assess the
property, and the cost to abate. Notice shall be served as set forth in Section
734.02.
(Ord. 21-15. Passed 6-25-15.)
734.04 APPEAL.
   The owner of a nuisance property who receives a notice from the Chief of
Police or his designee pursuant to Section
734.03(b) may request reconsideration of such notice by submitting a written
request to the Chief of Police within 30 days of the date of the notice.
   (a)    If, after a timely request for reconsideration is submitted, the
Chief of Police finds that the facts presented do not support the assessment of
costs, the Chief shall grant the request and rescind the notice. Otherwise, the
Chief shall deny the request.
   (b)    The property owner may appeal denial of the request by submitting a
written request within 30 days to the Chief of Police for a hearing before the
Commission on Citizen Relations.
   (c)    A request for reconsideration or appeal shall not stay any actions by
the city to abate any nuisance activity.
      (Ord. 21-15. Passed 6-25-15.)
734.05 COMMISSION ON CITIZEN RELATIONS.
   The Commission on Citizen Relations will hear appeals under this Chapter.
   (a)   There is created in Section
178.01, a Commission of Citizen Relations.
   (b)   The Commission on Citizen Relations shall hear any appeals made in
accordance with Chapter
734.
   (c)   Hearing of Appeal. In any such appeal, the City must show by a
preponderance of the evidence that each violation stated in the notice being
appealed has occurred, and that the intent of the City to assess the property
for abatement costs is justified. The City shall not have to show that there
has been a conviction for a criminal offense to show the existence of a
nuisance. The City shall be deemed to have failed to have met this standard if
the owner demonstrates by a preponderance of evidence that:
      (1)   He was not the owner at the time of any of the nuisance activity
that is the basis of the notice;
      (2)   He had knowledge of the nuisance activity, but has promptly and
vigorously taken all actions necessary to abate each nuisance including,
without limitation, compliance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. §§ 5321.17(C)
and 5321.04(A)(9); or
      (3)   He had no knowledge of the nuisance activity and could not, with
reasonable care and diligence, have known of the nuisance activity; and upon
receipt of the notice of the declaration of the property as a nuisance
property, he promptly took all actions necessary to abate the nuisance
including, without limitation, compliance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. §§
5321.17(C) and 5321.04(A)(9).
   (d)   Any appeal from a decision of the Commission on Citizen Relations
shall be made pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 2506.
      (Ord. 21-15. Passed 6-25-15.)
734.06  OTHER REMEDIES.
    (a)   After final decisions on any requests for reconsideration or further
appeals have been issued and the costs to abate have not been paid within 30
days of the notice of such decision, the costs of abatement shall be reported
to the Safety Service Director, who shall mail a statement of the amount
thereof to the owner of the property.
      (1)    If after 30 days such amount remains unpaid, the Safety Service
Director shall certify the total amount of the expenses, the name of the owner
of the land and a sufficient description of the premises to the County Auditor,
to be entered on the tax duplicate, to be a lien on the land from the date of
entry and to be collected as other taxes and assessments and returned to the
City pursuant to Ohio R.C. § 731.54.
   
   (b)   The declaration of a nuisance property, an order to abate a nuisance,
or the assessment of costs by the city on a property, do not affect or limit
the city's right or authority to bring criminal prosecution or other legal
action, including nuisance abatement and assessment as provided by law. (Ord.
21-15. Passed 6-25-15.)
CHAPTER 735
Emergency Alarm Equipment
735.01   Emergency alarms.
735.02   Permits.
735.03   Automatic dialing devices.
735.04   Local alarms.
735.05   Alarms connected at police headquarters.
735.06   False alarms.
735.07    Standards and operation.
735.08    Revocation, notice and appeal.
735.09    Liability of City.
735.10    Rules and regulations.
735.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
False alarms - see GEN. OFF.
509.05
 
 
735.01  EMERGENCY ALARMS.
   Emergency alarm equipment for the purpose of signaling an unauthorized
intrusion, the commission of an unlawful act, or the existence of an emergency
or all three, may be installed upon or within any residence, lawful business,
enterprise or agency within the corporate limits of the City, upon compliance
with the requirements and provisions set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 99-73. Passed 9-4-73.)
735.02 PERMITS.
   (a)    Permits are required for all alarm systems within the corporate
limits of the City, except those audible alarms affixed to automobiles. Permits
may be obtained upon due application and compliance with all applicable laws
and provisions of this chapter.
   (b)    Alarm installations existing at the time of passage of this chapter
shall be subject to all of the requirements and provisions set forth in this
chapter except that it shall be required that a permit be obtained within
thirty days of the effective date set forth herein for equipment or alarm
systems which were installed or operative prior to the effective date of this
chapter.
   (c)    The application for the permit shall be accompanied by documentary
evidence substantiating that the equipment had been installed prior to the
effective date.
(Ord.   99-73.   Passed 9-4-73.)
735.03  AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICES.
   (a)    No person shall use, cause to be used, or maintain for use, any
telephone device or telephone attachment that automatically selects and
produces a prerecorded message reporting an intrusion or emergency on any
telephone line allocated by the telephone company to the Police Department,
except a telephone line or lines which may be specifically designated by the
Police Chief for such purpose. Such designated telephone line or lines shall
terminate at the Police Station.
   (b)    The City may subscribe to one or more unlisted telephone lines for
the purpose of reporting burglaries and other emergencies, or other similar
purpose, and when such line is designated, as provided in subsection (a)
hereof, persons may, upon proper application and compliance with applicable
laws and provisions of this chapter be granted a permit to install and use a
device or devices which automatically select the designated telephone line for
the purpose of playing a recorded message or to otherwise report a burglary or
other emergency.
   (c)    For alarms of the type described in subsection (a) hereof, the
message shall first state, "This is a recording." The balance of the message
shall be appropriate to the purpose for which the alarm is installed, be clear,
concise and subject to approval of the Police Chief.
   (d)    For alarms of the type described in subsection (a) hereof, each such
device shall be programmed to first dial the police station, using the
designated unlisted telephone number described in subsection (b) hereof. The
device shall next dial a number selected by the applicant, such second number
being one at which a person having a key to the building from where the alarm
has been activated can normally be found. A third number may be programmed for
the next dialing. No more than three such dialings may be programmed and no
more than one may be programmed to select the Police Department number per
reporting incident, except under unusual circumstances and then only upon
approval of the Police Chief. No enforcement agency other than the Police
Department may be selected.
   (e)    The cost of providing the service described above, including any fee
or payment charged by the telephone company, shall be paid by the applicant.
   The cost of providing the service for automatic dialing alarms as described
above, including any fee or payment charged by the telephone company, shall be
paid by the applicant.
   The fee to be charged to the applicant shall be determined by dividing the
cost of phone service for the line designated to accept telephone alarms by the
number of holders of permits for automatic telephone dialer alarms, adding
fifteen percent for administration and handling, and rounding off the next
highest dollar, except that the minimum charge shall be thirty dollars ($30.00)
per half year. All fees charged shall be on a semiannual basis in advance.
Delinquency in excess of thirty days shall result in cancellation of the
alarm.   
(Ord. 99-73.   Passed 9-4-73.)
735.04 LOCAL ALARMS.
   (a)    A permit for the installation of a local alarm which, when activated,
sounds a horn, bell, buzzer, siren or other type of audible alarm, shall be
required if the sound created by the alarm is audible beyond the premises being
served. The Police Chief shall issue a permit upon due application and
compliance with the provisions of this chapter and all other applicable laws,
provided the level of intensity of sound of the alarm is controlled so that it
does not exceed fifty-five decibels at any location outside the premises being
served.
   (b)    All local alarms as described herein shall be equipped with a means
of automatically turning off the audible signal after a period of time
designated by the Police Chief.
(Ord. 99-73. Passed 9-4-73.)
735.05 ALARMS CONNECTED AT POLICE HEADQUARTERS.
   Upon proper application by any persons to connect their alarm system to the
consolidated police alarm panel, the Police Chief may approve installation if a
permit has been issued for the applicant's alarm system and if permission has
been obtained from the alarm company that maintains the panel at the police
station. Permission shall not be denied provided equipment is available and
compatible and provided charges are paid. The approval of the Police Chief must
have been gained before installation will be allowed.
(Ord. 99-73. Passed 9-4-73.)
735.06 FALSE ALARMS.
   (a)    A false alarm is defined as any signal actuated by an alarm system to
which the police respond which is not the result of a holdup, robbery,
burglary, or other crime, or emergency or malfunction. (Ord. 99-73. Passed 9-4-
73.)
   (b)    The permit holder of an alarm system or device shall pay to the City
a charge for each and every false alarm to which the police respond each
calendar year, according to the following schedule:
 
(1) First two false alarms                No charge
(2) Third false alarm                     $50.00
(3) Fourth and fifth false alarm          $75.00
(4) All additional false alarms over five $100.00 each
   No charge shall be made for the first two false alarms per alarm
installation in any calendar year, nor shall there be any charge to a false
alarm to which there is no response by police, nor when the cause has been
proven to be an act of God.
(Ord. 11-13. Passed 5-6-13.)
   (c)    Any charge for a false alarm, as provided for in this section, which
remains unpaid thirty days after date of invoice shall result in the
cancellation of the permit.
   (d)    No person shall intentionally cause a false alarm.
      (Ord.   99-73.    Passed 9-4-73.)
735.07  STANDARDS AND OPERATION.
   (a)    All equipment used in installations for which a permit is required
shall meet the applicable standards of the Underwriters' Laboratories and/or
other recognized industry standard. Applicant may be required to submit
evidence of the reliability and suitability of the equipment to be installed.
   (b)    The sensory mechanism used in connection with such devices must be
adjusted to suppress false indications of intrusion, so that the devices will
not be actuated by impulses due to transient pressure change in water pipes,
short flashes of light, wind noises such as the rattling or vibrating of doors
or windows, vehicular noise adjacent to the installation or other forces
unrelated to genuine alarms.
   (c)    All components comprising such a device must be maintained by the
owner or lessee in good repair to assure reliability of operation.
   (d)    Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases to a person an
automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the
City shall furnish that person with instructions as to the way the device
operates, along with maintenance instructions.
   (e)    Each alarm equipment supplier shall also furnish the Police Chief
with a copy of the instructions as to the way the device operates. If the
Police Chief finds such to be incomplete, unclear or otherwise inadequate, he
may require the alarm equipment supplier to have the same revised, to meet his
approval and then promptly distributed to persons for whom installations of
such devices are made.
   (f)    The Police Chief shall have the authority, at reasonable times and
upon oral notice, to enter upon any premises within the City, to inspect the
installation and operation of an automatic protection device or signaling
device, the purpose of which is to report an emergency to the police station.
   (g)    All equipment, the use or installation of which is subject to this
chapter, shall be maintained in good operating condition. The Police Chief may
require that repairs be made whenever he has determined that such are necessary
to assure proper operation.
(Ord. 99-73. Passed 9-4-73.)
735.08  REVOCATION, NOTICE AND APPEAL.
   For violation of the chapter, for failure to properly maintain an
installation or when the number of false alarms for any installation equals
twelve in any twelve month period, the Police Chief may serve written notice
upon a permit holder of intent to revoke his permit. Such notice shall be given
not less than seven days prior to revocation. The notice shall state the right
of the permit holder to appeal to the Director of Public Safety and Service. If
an appeal is filed in writing, the Director shall hold a hearing on the matter
and shall render a decision on the basis of facts presented. The Director's
decision shall be final. In the event no appeal is filed, the Police Chief
shall transmit all pertinent information to the Director, who shall cancel the
permit. The Police Chief shall take whatever steps are necessary to disconnect
the alarm.
(Ord.   99-73.   Passed 9-4-73.)
735.09 LIABILITY OF CITY.
   The issuance of any permit in promulgation of this chapter shall not
constitute acceptance by the City of any liability to maintain any equipment,
to answer alarms or for anything in connection thereto.
(Ord. 99-73. Passed 9-4-73.)
735.10 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Public Safety and Service shall make and enforce such rules
and regulations as he may deem necessary for the enforcement of the provisions
hereof and for the proper determination and collection of the fees and charges
herein provided.
(Ord. 99-73. Passed 9-4-73.)
735.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).   
(Ord.   99-73.   Passed 9-4-73.)
CHAPTER 741
Junk Shops and Junk Yards
741.01    Definition.
741.02    License required.
741.03    Issuance; fee; duration.
741.04    Display of sign.
741.05    Accessibility and inspection of stocks.
741.06    Purchase from drunkards and thieves prohibited.
741.07    Purchase from minor prohibited; hours.
741.08    Records; inspection.
741.09    Reports filed with Mayor.
741.10    Preparation of entries and reports.
741.11    Dismantling or storing on street prohibited.
741.12    Dismantling or storing on unfenced lot prohibited.
741.13    Fence requirements.
741.14    Burning rubbish in junk yardsprohibited.
741.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate junk shops and yards - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
License revocation for receiving stolen property - see Ohio R.C. 2961.03
Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
Obstructions in street - see TRAF.
311.01

521.08
Noxious or offensive odors - see GEN. OFF.
521.09
Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
545.18
 
 
741.01 DEFINITION.
   "Junk shop" means any place, shop, store, wagon, truck or other vehicle or
other place of business where or in which is collected, stored or kept
secondhand articles of any kind, scrap iron, old metal, canvas, rope, branded
bottles, junk, lead pipe or any other article of any kind usually found in a
junk shop, except plow irons, old stoves and furniture.
(1963 Code §741.01)
741.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall maintain, keep or conduct a junk shop within the corporate
limits of the City without first having obtained a junk shop license to do so
as provided in this chapter.
(1963 Code §741.02)
741.03 ISSUANCE; FEE; DURATION.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to grant for a period of one year a license
to any suitable person applying therefore authorizing such person to conduct
and maintain a junk shop or junk yard within the corporate City limits, for
property located in an area zoned I-2 Heavy Industrial only, upon payment to
the Mayor for such license in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
However, where the applicant does not have a permanent place of business and
carries on his business in a wagon or other vehicle or sells or removes his
junk from within the corporate limits of the City each day, then the license
fees shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each and every day such applicant
desires to conduct his business within the corporate limits of the City.
(Ord. 87-00. Passed 6-19-00.)
741.04 DISPLAY OF SIGN.
   Every licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall place and keep in
a conspicuous place in or upon his junk shop a sign which displays the name of
such junk dealer, his license number and the words "JUNK DEALER" legibly
printed thereon.
(1963 Code §741.04)
741.05 ACCESSIBILITY AND INSPECTION OF STOCKS.
   The junk bought, collected or received by any licensee under the provisions
of this chapter, except one who does not have a place of business in a
building, shall be kept in an accessible place in the building or other place
where such articles are purchased, received or stored. Such junk shall be
subject to inspection by the Police Chief, any member of the Police Department
and all other persons who are authorized by the Police Chief or by the Mayor to
make such inspection. (1963 Code §741.05)
741.06 PURCHASE FROM DRUNKARDS AND THIEVES PROHIBITED.
   No licensee under the provisions of this chapter or any of his employees
shall directly or indirectly buy or receive any junk from any intoxicated
person, habitual drunkard, person known to be a thief or an associate of
thieves, a receiver of stolen property or any other person he has reason to
suspect of being such.
(1963 Code §741.06)
741.07 PURCHASE FROM MINOR PROHIBITED; HOURS.
   No person shall purchase or receive by sale, barter, exchange or otherwise
any article mentioned in Section
741.01 from a minor or apprentice, knowing or having reason to believe him to
be such, or from any person between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.
(1963 Code §741.07)
741.08 RECORDS; INSPECTION.
   Every licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall make on the day of
the transaction and keep in a record book for that purpose a record of the name
and address of every person from whom any junk is bought or received, or to
whom any junk is sold or exchanged, and a correct list of all junk bought,
collected or received. Every entry shall be numbered consecutively beginning
with number one. All such licensees shall at all times keep such record open
for inspection by the Police Chief, to any member of the Police Department and
to all other persons who are authorized by the Police Chief or by the Mayor to
make such inspection.
(1963 Code §741.08)
741.09  REPORTS FILED WITH MAYOR.
   All licensees under the provisions of this chapter shall file with the Mayor
on or before 5:00 p.m. of the first day of each and every month a true copy of
all records made in the record book, required to be kept in Section
741.08, during the month immediately preceding. However, such licensees who go
about with a wagon or other vehicle and purchase or obtain by exchange or
otherwise any of the articles mentioned in Section
741.01 and not having a place of business in a building shall be required to
file with the Mayor on or before 5:00 p.m. of each and every day they so
conduct their business, a copy of all records made in such record book during
that day. The record or report required to be filed with the Mayor by this
section may be a carbon copy of the original record. The authenticity of such
report shall be sworn to before the Mayor by the person or proper officer of
the firm or corporation filing the same.
(1963 Code §741.09)
741.10 PREPARATION OF ENTRIES AND REPORTS.
   All entries, records and lists required by this chapter shall be written in
ink or with an indelible lead pencil. No language other than the English
language shall be used thereon. No entry shall be erased, obliterated or
defaced.
(1963 Code §741.10)
741.11 DISMANTLING OR STORING ON STREET PROHIBITED.
   No person shall wreck, dismantle or store for commercial purposes any motor-
driven vehicle or junk on the sidewalks, public streets or other public places
within the corporate limits of the City.
(1963 Code §741.11)
741.12  DISMANTLING OR STORING ON UNFENCED LOT PROHIBITED.
   No person shall wreck, dismantle or store for commercial purposes, the
wreckage of parts of motor-driven vehicles, wastepaper, cardboard or any used
building materials on any open lot or parcel of ground not enclosed in a fence
meeting the requirements prescribed in Section
741.13. (1963 Code §741.12)
741.13 FENCE REQUIREMENTS.
   The fence required by Section
741.12 shall be not less than six feet in height and shall be subject to the
approval of the Fire Chief and the City Fire Inspector. Such fence shall be
constructed on the building line and shall be constructed to withstand wind
pressure of thirty pounds per square foot.
(1963 Code §741.13)
741.14  BURNING RUBBISH IN JUNK YARDS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall burn any junk, rubbish or refuse within the confines of any
junk yard within the corporate limits of the City or on the lands or streets
adjacent thereto, nor shall any person cause any fires to be started or
maintained on the premises of any junk yard for the purpose of consuming or
burning junk, rubbish or refuse of any kind whatsoever.
(1963 Code § 741.14)
741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor on a first offense; and of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree on
each subsequent offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which an offense occurs or continues.
(Ord. 80-84. Passed 11-5-84.)
CHAPTER 742
Local Bidder Preference
742.01   Local preference.
 
 
742.01 LOCAL PREFERENCE.   
   (a)   The Board of Control in its sole discretion in determining the lowest
and best bidder, is authorized to award locally funded contracts to local
bidders whose bid is not more than five percent (5%) higher than the low dollar
bid submitted by a non-local bidder, for the first $100,000 of any counter bid
plus three percent (3%) for any amount over $100,000 of any contract bid.
   (b)   Local bidder shall be defined as an individual or business entity who:
      (1)   Has a principal place of business located within the corporate
limits of the City of Alliance as registered in official documents filed with
the Secretary of State’s Office, State of Ohio; or   
      (2)   Holds a valid vendor’s license which indicates that its place of
business is located within the corporate limits of the City of Alliance; or
      (3)   Utilizes vendors, suppliers or subcontractors which have as their
principal place of business a location within the corporate limits of the City
of Alliance; but only to the extent of the value of the contract bid that is
directly attributed to the local vendors, suppliers or subcontractors.
   (c)   All future contract specifications and/or bid documents that are
distributed by the City of Alliance for the purposes of soliciting bids for
goods and/or services shall prominently display the following notice:
NOTICE
   Prospective bidders will take note that the City of Alliance shall have
discretion through its Board of Control, to determine that any bid submitted by
a local bidder or a portion of that bid which is directly attributed to local
vendors, suppliers or subcontractors which is not more than five percent (5%)
higher than the low dollar bid is, in fact, the lowest and best bid for
purposes of awarding this contract for the first $100,000 of any contract bid
plus three percent (3%) for any amount over $100,000. Local bidder shall be
defined as an individual’s business entity who:
   (a)   Has a principal place of business located within the corporate limits
of the City of Alliance as registered in the official documents filed with the
Secretary of State, State of Ohio; or
   (b)   Holds a valid vendor’s license which indicates that its place of
business is located within the corporate limits of the City of Alliance; or
      (c)   Utilizes vendors, suppliers or subcontractors which have as their
principal place of business a location within the corporate limits of the City
of Alliance; but only to the extent of the value of the contract bid that is
directly attributed to the local vendors, suppliers or subcontractors.
   (d)   Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, this section shall be
applicable to all contracts for the purchase of materials, equipment, supplies
or services which are purchased, leased or constructed at a cost in excess of
$5,000 and which require bidding pursuant to Ohio Revised Code Section 735.05
through 735.09 and Ohio Revised Code 737.03.
       (Ord. 88-01. Passed 8-6-01.)
CHAPTER 743
Oil and Gas Wells
743.01   Permit required.
743.02   Permit application required; fee.
743.03   Application requirements; map and easements.
743.04   Investigation; Council approval or rejection of application.
743.05   Rejection of permit by Council; fee refund.
743.06   Insurance; liability.
743.07   Owner’s permission required.
743.08   Location requirements.
743.09   Failure to commence work; termination of permit.
743.10   Emergency information.
743.11   Fence required; locking devices.
743.12   Waste drainage.
743.13   Public streets and access roads.
743.14   Use of gasoline motors; noise.
743.15   Painting equipment required.
743.16   Restoration of premises.
743.17   Dike required.
743.18   Sealing wells required.
743.19   Flares.
743.20   Safety requirements.
743.21   Additional permits.
743.22   Compliance with State regulations.
743.23   Inspection.
743.24   Compliance with chapter required.
743.25   Revocation of permit.
743.26   Abandoning wells.
743.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1509
Nuisances - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3767.01 et seq.
Oil and gas well drilling - see OAC Ch. 1501:9-1, 1501:9-9
 
 
743.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall commence to drill a well for oil or gas
or operate a producing well within the corporate limits of the City, except
pursuant to a permit issued by the Mayor, as hereinafter provided. Each well
shall require a separate permit.
(Ord.   77-67.   Passed 8-7-67.)
743.02 PERMIT APPLICATION REQUIRED; FEE.
   Any person, firm or corporation desiring to engage in the drilling of a well
for oil or gas, or to carry on the operation of an oil or gas well, within the
corporate limits of the City, shall make application to the Mayor upon such
forms as may be prescribed for a permit to do so. Such application shall be
accompanied by a fee of fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500). There shall be filed
a separate application and fee for each well contemplated.
   No refund or any permit fee or part thereof shall be returned for a dry hole
or for failure to exercise the privilege to drill upon a site covered by such a
permit.
(Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.03 APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS; MAP AND EASEMENTS.
   It shall be the duty of the applicant at the time of presenting such
application to supply and attach to the application a map showing the exact
location of the proposed well and sludge pit and the location of storage tank
batteries and access road if there is a producing well. Such map shall remain
on file with the Mayor for future reference. The map shall be drawn to scale
and show the lot lines of all properties in the area unitized for the well, the
location of buildings and structures in the unit and the names of each of the
property owners shall be shown on the map within the drilling unit.
   Each application shall have attached with it copies of any existing
easements or options for easements for pipe lines and/or storage tanks if there
is a producing well. The copy of such easement shall be accompanied by a map
showing where such easement crosses private property. (Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-
67.)
743.04 INVESTIGATION; COUNCIL APPROVAL OR REJECTION OF APPLICATION.
   The Mayor or his agent shall make an Investigation of the premises for which
an oil or gas well permit is sought. Included in this investigation shall be an
inspection by the Building Department and the Fire Department.
   When the investigations required by this section are completed, the
application together with a written report of the investigations including
comments and recommendations made by the Building Department and Fire
Department shall be submitted to Council, which shall grant a permit or reject
the application. (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.05 REJECTION OF PERMIT BY COUNCIL; FEE REFUND.
   Any provision of this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding, Council, in
its sole discretion, shall have the right to reject any application for a
permit where by reason of the location of the proposed well and the character
and value of the permanent improvements already erected, the use to which the
land and surroundings are adapted for civic purposes, for sanitary or health
and safety reasons, or other unspecified reasons, the drilling of an oil or gas
well would be detrimental to the City and its inhabitants. Council shall also
not be required to consider the issuance or denial of prior applications for
permits in making its decision to grant or not to grant an application for a
permit.
   When a permit is refused the fee deposited with the application shall be
returned to the applicant. (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.06 INSURANCE; LIABILITY.
   If decided upon affirmative vote by a majority of members elected to Council
that a permit shall be issued, the Mayor shall issue such permit as authorized
by Council only if there is submitted to the Mayor a certificate of insurance
that includes the following requirements:
   (a)    That the applicant has liability coverage for property damage and
personal injury in the amount of not less than a combined one million dollars
($1,000,000) single limit per occurrence with an annual aggregate limit of two
million dollars ($2,000,000);
   (b)    That said insurance policy shall specifically include liability
coverage for the applicant covering the drilling and operation of the well
including liability coverage for a blowout and crater in the drilling of such
well;
   (c)    That said insurance policy shall remain in effect and be maintained
by the applicant until such well is plugged and pulled;
   (d)   That the insurance carrier is required to be an "admitted carrier"
with the State of Ohio or have a B+ (B plus) rating or higher as rated by A.M.
Best;
   (e)    That the insurance agent who issues the policy show evidence of
errors and omission insurance in the amount of one million dollars
($1,000,000);
   (f)    That the insurance carrier is required to give the City of Alliance
written notice within thirty (30) days of cancellation of both the policy
covering the applicant and the errors and omission policy covering the
insurance agent.
   The permittee shall pay to the owners of any realty, crops, buildings,
improvements, goods or chattels located in the area, except persons who are
parties to the drilling unit, any extra cost of insurance on such property
imposed by reason of granting of the permit or the operations carried on
thereunder. The permittee will hold the City free and harmless from any and all
liability growing out of the granting of such permit. (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-
21-92.)
743.07  OWNER'S PERMISSION REQUIRED.
   No permit shall be issued for the drilling of a well except upon ground
owned by the applicant or held by the applicant under an oil and gas lease or
drilling contract from the owner, giving the owner's permission to drill the
well. Nothing contained in this chapter, nor any permit issued hereunder, shall
be deemed to grant any right or license to the permittee to enter upon or
occupy in any respect in the drilling or production operations any land not
owned by him except by the written permission of the owner. (Ord. 77-67. Passed
8-7-67.)
743.08  LOCATION REQUIREMENTS.
   No permit shall be issued to drill a well for the production of oil or gas
unless the proposed well, sludge pit, and storage tank batteries are located:
   (a)    In an Industrial Zone designated by I-l or I-2 under the Zoning
Ordinance presently in force or as hereafter amended.
   (b)    Upon a tract or drilling unit containing not less than forty acres
which forty acre tract may include acreage located in districts zoned for
industrial, commercial, residential, and/or college land uses;
   (c)   Not less than 230 feet from a boundary line of the subject tract or
drilling unit;
   (d)    Not less than 250 feet from any building designed for human occupancy
or building where the public assembles or congregates;
   (e)    Not less than 150 feet from any road, highway, street or alley;
   The distance requirements in items c, d, and e may be reduced for gas and
oil wells located in Industrial Zones if, in the opinion of Council, the
distance requirements present an undue hardship to the applicant and the
reduced distances do not present an undue threat to the public health, safety
and welfare. Council shall be the sole authority permitted to grant said
exceptions.
   Proposed sites will be considered from the perspective of both existing and
future development and should not be located so as to be potentially
detrimental to the future use and development of the parcel(s) upon which the
well is to be located or any of the adjoining parcels.
   All future buildings to be constructed that are designed for human occupancy
or buildings where the public assembles or congregates shall be located at
least 250 feet from any existing well or storage tank batteries. This distance
may be reduced if, in the opinion of Council, the distance requirement presents
an undue hardship to the owner and the reduced distance does not present an
undue threat to the public health, safety and welfare. Council shall be the
sole authority permitted to grant said exception. (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-
92.)
743.09 FAILURE TO COMMENCE WORK; TERMINATION OF PERMIT.
   When a permit required by Section
743.01 has been issued, such permit shall terminate and become inoperative,
without any action on the part of the City, unless within ninety days from the
date of issue, actual drilling of the well shall have been commenced, and after
the drilling of a well has commenced, the cessation for a like period of the
drilling operations, shall operate to terminate and cancel the permit and the
well shall be deemed abandoned for all purposes of this chapter, and no person
shall thereafter drill or operate any such well without the issuance of another
permit. (Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.10 EMERGENCY INFORMATION.
   The permittee shall supply to the Police Chief and Fire Chief the name,
address and telephone number of the persons responsible for the operation and
maintenance of each well for which a permit is issued so that some responsible
person may be reached at any time in case of an emergency.
   The permittee shall also place on both the well and the tank battery a sign
indicating the following:
   (a)    Name of the well;
   (b)    State of Ohio permit number;
   (c)   Name, address and phone number of the well operator;
   (d)    Name and phone number of the person to call in the event of an
emergency;
   (e)    Alternate name in case those parties cannot be reached.
   To enable the information to be read from a distance in case of emergency,
the lettering on the tank battery shall be bright yellow, painted, stenciled,
or decal, 4 inch height x 3/4 inch thickness x 3 inch wide.
   The requirements of this section shall apply to all existing wells in the
City of Alliance. (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.11 FENCE REQUIRED; LOCKING DEVICES.
   A permittee shall maintain a temporary fence around the drilling site in
accordance with good oil field practice. Should a well be a producer, the
permittee shall, upon completion of such well, construct a fence around the
well pump, drainage pits and other installations or equipment used at oil well
installations within the corporate limits of the Clty. Such fences shall be
chain link, six feet in height with three strands of barbed wire at the top and
shall be maintained in good repair. Locking devices shall be used on the tank
valves and a locked gate shall be placed on the tank stairway. (Ord. 128-92.
Passed 12-21-92.)
743.12 WASTE DRAINAGE.
   No waste, sludge, water or effluents of any type where an oil or gas well is
being drilled or operated shall in any manner be emptied or drained into any
storm or sanitary sewer of the City or in any open watercourse. All sludge
shall be confined to a pit during the drilling period and shall, after
completion, be covered to the original ground level, except a small pit for
water overflow. (Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.13 PUBLIC STREETS AND ACCESS ROADS.
   All permittes shall provide a twenty five thousand dollar ($25,000) road
bond or other financial guarantee satisfactory to the Mayor which shall be
placed with the City Auditor to insure that all roads are properly improved
from any damage incurred from the drilling of an oil or gas well. Bond is to
remain in effect until such time as the actual drilling of the well is
completed, the drilling equipment is removed, and the Mayor or his duly
designated agent has determined that all damage to roads has been corrected to
his satisfaction.
   All permittees shall use care at a drilling site to keep the area around
such drilling site free of mud which may be carried on the public streets by
any vehicle or other equipment used at a drilling site. Should any mud be
carried on the public streets from a drilling site, the permittee may be
required to clean up such streets to the satisfaction of the Mayor or his duly
designated agent.
   The Mayor shall have the authority to request a permittee to take specific
steps to reduce mud at any given location. Failure of a permittee to clean up
the public streets to the satisfaction of the Mayor, or failure to take steps
to reduce mud at a given location as requested by the Mayor shall be grounds
for revocation of a permit and shall further be a misdemeanor as set forth in
Section
743.99.
   Prior to the commencement of the drilling operation and prior to the
installation of any tanks, the permit holder shall provide access roads, to the
satisfaction of the City Engineer, to all well and tank sites. All tank access
roads shall be constructed of suitable slag, gravel, crushed stone or other
road surface material, be of good width to allow travel by firefighting
equipment, and be maintained in good condition free of mud and dust.
(Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.14 USE OF GASOLINE MOTORS; NOISE.
   During the drilling stage all motors shall be provided with a muffler, or
mufflers, which shall be of sufficient capacity to reduce noise to a maximum
sound level of all operations of seventy (70) decibels at a three hundred foot
(300') radius during maximum noise production periods. In the event that the
decibel limit has been violated, the Mayor shall order the permittee to cease
drilling until adequate measures are taken to reduce the decibel level equal to
or less than seventy (70) decibels at a distance of three hundred feet ( 300')
.
   Well pumps may be operated with gasoline motors, provided such motors are
properly muffled to reduce noise to a minimum and where such gasoline motors
are not properly muffled Council may require electric motors for the well pump.
   In the determination of what constitutes a properly muffled gasoline motor
the decision of Council shall be final. (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.15 PAINTING EQUIPMENT REQUIRED.
   All equipment, including tanks, shall be painted at the time of installing
and every two years thereafter. (Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.16 RESTORATION OF PREMISES.
   The permittee shall restore the streets, sidewalks, Municipal utilities and
other public places of the City which may have been damaged or disturbed in the
operations of drilling or preparing to drill or connected with drilling, to
their former condition.
   The permittee shall clear the area of all litter, rubbish, machinery,
derricks, building, oil or other substances used or allied to the use of
drilling or producing operations, when such machinery or materials are no
longer necessary for drilling operations or maintenance of the well. In
addition, all drainage pits used in the maintenance of the well shall be lined
with polyethylene or similar material to prevent seepage. The pit shall be kept
free of sludge and other objectionable substances and shall be maintained in a
reasonably dry and clean condition.
(Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.17 DIKE REQUIRED.
   Before any oil shall be stored in any above ground storage tanks, there
shall be constructed completely around all such tanks a dike or earthen fill of
well-compacted earth of sufficient capacity to store the total capacity of all
such tanks so enclosed. (Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.18 SEALING WELLS REQUIRED.
   It shall be the duty of the permittee to seal gas and oil wells to protect
fresh water wells from salt pollution in such proper manner as is in accordance
with good oil field practice.
(Ord. 77-67.   Passed 8-7-67.)
743.19 FLARES.
   Flares are not permitted on gas and oil wells in the City of Alliance.
(Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.20 SAFETY REQUIREMENTS.
   Permittees shall comply with the following safety requirements for all oil
and gas wells in the City of Alliance:
   (a)    All drilling rigs shall be provided with a fire extinguisher of not
less than twenty pounds, dry chemical.
   (b)    Shut-in valves on well heads and tank batteries shall be painted
bright yellow for identification purposes to assist emergency shut-in of the
well site if necessary.
   (c)    All wells shall comply with the standards set forth in API
Recommended Practice 2003 Protection Against Ignitions Arising Out of Static,
Lightening and Stray Currents;
   (d)    All wells shall be equipped with an emergency shutoff switch or
Murphy switch;
   (e)    All tank batteries shall be constructed to prevent the continuous
release of gas or vapor;
   (f)    A low pressure PSI relief valve shall be installed on the vent stack.
      (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.21 ADDITIONAL PERMITS.
   No material, drilling rigs or other equipment shall be placed upon any
drilling site until all necessary permits have been obtained in accordance with
City ordinances and the laws of Ohio. (Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.22 COMPLIANCE WITH STATE REGULATIONS.
   All permittees shall, in addition to the regulations set forth herein,
comply with all statutes, rules and regulations promulgated by any department
or division of the State relative to the drilling, operation, maintenance,
pulling and plugging of oil and gas wells.
(Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.23 INSPECTION.
   Council or its representatives shall have the authority at any time to enter
upon property where a drilling site is contemplated or where a well is
operating or is in the process of being drilled for the purpose of inspecting
such site and equipment and any and all other things necessary to assure
compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
   It shall be the duty of the Fire Department and the Building Department to
inspect all oil and gas well sites in the City of Alliance once each year and
make reports to the Mayor. Such inspections and subsequent reports may be done
jointly. (Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.24 COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER REQUIRED.
   Failure to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
grounds to refuse a permit to drill a well or shall be grounds to revoke a
permit already issued. Revocation of such permit shall remove the rights of the
permittee to drill or operate for oil or gas until such permittee has complied
with the provisions of this chapter. Operations carried on by the permittee
after the revocation of such permit shall be a misdemeanor, punishable under
the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.25 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   The Mayor is hereby granted the authority to cancel and revoke any permit
when it appears that fraud or misrepresentation was practiced in obtaining a
permit or that the permittee has failed to comply with the terms of this
chapter after notice of any violation thereof. An appeal from the decision of
the Mayor to revoke a permit shall be made with Council, which shall have the
authority and power to review such revocations. (Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
743.26 ABANDONING WELLS.
   In the event that a well is abandoned, it shall be the duty of the
permittee, owner or lessee to notify the Mayor and the Fire Chief of such
abandonment before the well has been abandoned and the equipment removed. All
permittees shall be required to plug or pull a well site on abandonment and
remove all above ground appurtenances and return ground to original grade and
condition, and follow any other rules and regulations promulgated by any
department or division of the State of Ohio relative to pulling, plugging and
abandoning oil and gas wells.
(Ord. 128-92. Passed 12-21-92.)
743.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day's violation of any provision shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 77-67. Passed 8-7-67.)
CHAPTER 745
Poolrooms, Billiard Rooms and Bowling Alleys
745.01    Definition.
745.02    License required.
745.03    Application.
745.04    General license fee.
745.05    Fee for combination billiard room and bowling alley.
745.06    Revocation or refusal.
745.07    Licensee requirements.
745.08    Sanitation required; right of inspection.
745.09    Hours and loitering.
745.10    Regulations to be posted.
745.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.51, 715.61
Curfew - see GEN. OFF.
509.10
Gambling- see GEN. OFF.
517.02 et seq.
Liquor control - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
529
Amusements- see BUS. REG. Ch.
709
Coin-operated devices - see BUS. REG. Ch.
729
 
 
745.01 DEFINITION.
   "Poolroom" or “billiard room” includes any sport shop, smoke shop, cigar
store or other similar business or location by whatever name or nature known.
(Ord. 64-59. Passed 10-5-59.)
745.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate or conduct a billiard room, poolroom or bowling
alley within the corporate limits of the City for money or other reward without
having first obtained a license therefor from the Mayor.
(1963 Code §745.02)
745.03  APPLICATION.
   Every person desiring to open, conduct, operate or maintain what is commonly
known as a public poolroom, billiard room or bowling alley shall make
application to the Mayor for a license to do so. Such application shall be made
upon a form to be furnished to the applicant and shall state the applicant's
full name and address, including the street and number of his proposed place of
business, age, date of final naturalization papers if foreign born and place of
birth. If the applicant is a firm or corporation, such information shall be
given with respect to the several members of the firm or the officers of the
corporation. In the case of a society or association unincorporated, such
information shall be given respecting the officer thereof.
   The application shall further set forth the name of the owner of the
premises and his address, on what floor of such premises the business is to be
conducted, whether the applicant has previously been engaged in such business,
and when and whether such applicant has ever had a license suspended or revoked
for the operation of such business. No license shall be granted to any person
who is not a citizen of the United States or who has been convicted of a
felony.
(Ord. 158-59. Passed 10-5-59.)
745.04 GENERAL LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee for each billiard room, poolroom or bowling alley operated
within the corporate limits of the City shall be twelve dollars and fifty cents
($12.50) per annum and a further charge of four dollars ($4.00) for each table
or alley operated and installed.
(1963 Code §745.04)
745.05 FEE FOR COMBINATION BILLIARD ROOM AND BOWLING ALLEY.
   If any person operates both a billiard room and bowling alley under the same
management and in the same building, then such person shall pay but one annual
room charge. In addition, such person shall pay the annual rates for additional
tables and alleys as provided in Section
745.04.
(1963 Code §745.05)
745.06 REVOCATION OR REFUSAL.
   The Mayor shall revoke any license issued by virtue of this chapter at any
time that the licensee is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter. No permit or license shall be issued to such licensee for a
period of one year thereafter, nor shall such licensee operate a poolroom,
billiard room or bowling alley under a license issued to any other person. The
Mayor shall also have the right and authority to refuse any license issued by
virtue of this chapter at any time that such licensee is convicted of any other
crime or misdemeanor under the laws of the State or of the United States.
(Ord. 159-59. Passed 10-5-59.)
745.07 LICENSEE REQUIREMENTS.
   Each licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall comply with the
following requirements:
   (a)    Gambling. No licensee shall permit to be played, nor shall anyone
present in any poolroom, billiard room or bowling alley play, any game upon any
table or alley for money or any other valuable thing nor shall they permit or
engage in the playing of cards, the operation of punchboards, the operation of
raffling devices, the use of a pea ball or other game of chance, or any form of
gambling in any poolroom, billiard room or bowling alley, or in any room where
pool or billiard tables or bowling alleys are located.
      (Ord. 161-59. Passed 10-5-59.)
   (b)    Disorderly Premises. No licensee shall suffer or permit the licensed
premises to become disorderly.
   (c)    Minors. No licensee shall suffer or permit any minor under the age of
eighteen years to enter or remain in such billiard room or poolroom unless
accompanied by his parent, nor shall such licensee permit such minor to play
any game therein.
   (d)    Hours of Operation. No licensee shall keep such billiard room or
poolroom or table open on Sunday or operate the same between the hours of 12:00
midnight and 7:00 a.m. on the other days of the week. No bowling alley shall be
kept open or be operated between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., nor on
Sundays from 2:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m.
   (e)    Alcoholic Beverages. No licensee shall sell, furnish, possess, give
away or suffer to be sold, possessed or given away in such billiard room or
poolroom any intoxicating liquor, including any and all liquids which are
prohibited by law to be sold, furnished, possessed or given away, unless such
licensee is the holder of a valid permit issued by the Ohio Department of
Liquor Control.
   (f)    Obstructing View. No licensee shall suffer or permit the windows or
doors in such billiard room, poolroom, bowling alley or place where any
billiard or pool tables are maintained to be screened, curtained or otherwise
obstructed at any time of the day or night so as to prevent a full, clear and
unobstructed view of such poolroom, billiard room or bowling alley.
      (1963 Code §745.07)
745.08 SANITATION REQUIRED; RIGHT OF INSPECTION.
   All poolrooms, billiard rooms and bowling alleys shall at all times be kept
in a clean, healthful and sanitary condition. All police, sanitary and other
enforcement officials of the City shall have the right to enter therein at any
time during business hours or at any time the premises is occupied for the
purpose of inspection. No person shall prevent or hinder any enforcement
official from making a full inspection of such premises.
(Ord. 160-59. Passed 10-5-59.)
745.09  HOURS AND LOITERING.
   Any person found loitering about any poolroom, billiard room or any room
adjoining thereto or having access from such room, between the hours of 12:00
midnight and 7:00 a.m., or on Sunday, other than the owner or operator thereof
or a person responding to an emergency, shall be deemed a suspicious person.
Any owner, operator or manager of a poolroom or billiard room who permits any
person to loiter about the premises between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:
00 a.m. or on Sunday, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Ord. 162-59. Passed 10-5-59.)
745.10  REGULATIONS TO BE POSTED.
   A copy of all ordinances pertaining to the regulation and operation of
poolrooms, billiard rooms or bowling alleys shall be posted in a conspicuous
place within each poolroom, billiard room or bowling alley operated within the
City.
(Ord. 163-59. Passed 10-5-59.)
745.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which an offense occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 747
Refuse Hauling
747.01    License required.
747.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
Employment of scavengers - see Ohio R.C. 3707.39
Disposal and transportation upon public ways - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20 et seq.
Vehicle loads dropping, sifting, leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
 
 
747.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)    A “commercial refuse hauler license” is hereby established which will
