percent (0.5%) or more of alcohol by volume which are fit to use for beverage
purposes, from whatever source and by whatever process produced, by whatever
name called and whether they are medicated, proprietary or patented. Such
phrase includes wine as defined in Ohio R.C. 4301.01 even if it contains less
than four percent (4%) of alcohol by volume, mixed beverages as defined in Ohio
R.C. 4301.01 even if they contain less than four percent (4%) of alcohol by
volume, cider, alcohol and all solids and confections which contain alcohol.
   (m)    Beer means all beverages brewed or fermented wholly or in part from
malt products and containing one-half of one percent (0.5%) or more, but not
more than twelve (12%) of alcohol by volume. (Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.04 COMPUTERIZED SWEEPSTAKES DEVICE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall display for purpose of use any computerized sweepstakes
device in the City without having first obtained a license therefore as
provided in this chapter, which license shall be designated as a computerized
sweepstakes license. A separate license is required for each such computerized
sweepstakes device.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.05 SWEEPSTAKES TERMINAL CAFÉ LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct or operate a sweepstakes terminal café in the City
of Alliance without having first obtained a license therefore as provided in
this chapter, which license shall be designated as a sweepstakes terminal café
license.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.06  AUTHORITY OF SAFETY SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   Authority is hereby established and vested in the Safety Service Director to
consider the applications for licenses under this chapter, conduct
investigations thereon and issue or deny issuance of such licenses based upon
the criteria set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.07  NATURE OF LICENSES.
   (a)    All Licenses. All licenses issued under this chapter shall have the
following characteristics:
      (1)    Each such license shall be an annual license which covers a period
from January 1 through December 31 in each calendar year unless earlier
suspended or revoked.
      (2)    Each such license shall vest a personal privilege but not any
property rights in the licensee.
      (3)    Each such license shall be required to be displayed continuously
in a conspicuous place upon the premise for which it is issued.
      (4)    Each such license shall be in the name of the applicant.
      (5)    Each such license shall be neither assignable nor transferable,
either as to person or location.
      (6)    Each such license, if lost, destroyed or mutilated, upon
application within thirty (30) days thereof may be replaced by a replacement
license issued by the Safety Director bearing the word "Replacement" across its
face and bearing the same license number as the license which it replaces.
  
   (b)    Computerized Sweepstakes Device Licenses. All computerized
sweepstakes device licenses issued under this chapter shall have the following
characteristics:
      (1)    Each such license shall be issued for an individual computerized
sweepstakes device only.
      (2)    Each such license shall specify the name and address of each
licensee, and the manufacturer, model number and serial number of the
computerized sweepstakes device for which it was issued.
      (3)    Each such license, if changed, mutilated, erased or in any manner
defaced, shall be void, and any amusement devices which the same shall purport
to license shall be deemed an unlicensed amusement device.
   (c)    Sweepstakes Terminal Café Licenses. All sweepstakes terminal café
licenses issued under this chapter shall have the following characteristics:
      (1)    Each such license shall be issued only for an individual business
at an individual premise.
      (2)    Each such license shall specify the name and address of each
licensee, and the manufacturer, model number and serial number of each
computerized sweepstakes device located upon the premises for which it was
issued.
         (Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.08 PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING LICENSES
   (a)    Applications for Licenses. All applications for licenses under this
chapter shall be in writing on a form approved by and filed with the Safety
Service Director. The application shall be signed by the owner or owners and
shall contain information required by this section supplied in detail as to
each such person, including general and limited partners, or partnerships,
shareholders of corporations and principals of any other type of business
entity which owns twenty-five percent (25%) of the membership, voting or
pecuniary interest of the entity. In the event that no person owns twenty-five
percent (25%) or more of the sweepstakes terminal café, such application shall
be signed by an authorized representative of the sweepstakes terminal café. All
applications shall contain a statement that the information contained therein
is complete, accurate and truthful to the best knowledge of all applicants.
   (b)    Contents of Applications.  The Application shall contain the
following information as to all owners:
      (1)    True name and all other names used in the past five (5) years;
      (2)    Date of birth;
      (3)    Permanent home address and all other home addresses used in the
past five (5) years;
      (4)    Business and home telephone numbers;
      (5)    A statement as to whether or not the owner has been convicted of
any crime other than traffic offenses and, if convicted, the date and court of
conviction, the specific crime convicted of, and the penalty imposed;
      (6)    A statement as to whether or not the owner has ever conducted a
sweepstakes terminal café, and, if so, the specific location of the café and
the dates of such operation;
      (7)    A statement as to whether the owner, or any sweepstakes which the
owner has previously operated, has been notified of any violation of Federal,
State or local laws or regulations.
      (8)    A description of the nature and operation of the main type of
business activity to be conducted upon the premises, and the hours and days of
operation.
      (9)    A description of the nature and operation of any business to be
conducted in conjunction with the sweepstakes terminal café, and the
anticipated percentage of gross revenue to be derived from each respective
business;
      (10)    The address and telephone number of the premises and the
business, if different from the premises;
      (11)    The name under which the business and premises will be operated;
      (12)    A statement as to whether or not the owner will directly operate
the sweepstakes terminal café, or whether an operator who is not an owner will
operate it, and if the latter, the application shall contain information
required by this section supplied in detail as to each such operator;
      (13)    A floor plan of the premises and the immediate vicinity drawn to
scale, showing the square footage and placement of the computerized sweepstakes
devices, exits, windows, storage spaces, bicycle storage racks and off street
parking;
      (14)    The name, address and telephone number of the agent of the
business upon whom service of process can effectively and validly be made;
      (15)    The number, type, name, model and manufacturer's serial number of
each computerized sweepstakes device requested to be licensed;
      (16)    The name and address of the owner, distributor and manufacturer
of each computerized sweepstakes device requested to be licensed;
      (17)    Specification of terms of the agreement governing the acquisition
and installation of each computerized sweepstakes device requested to be
licensed;
      (18)    A description as to the nature and type of property or services
which will be sold or supplied upon the premises;
      (19)    A copy of the title or lease to the premises;
      (20)    A copy of the Articles of Incorporation, if the owner is a
corporation;
      (21)    A copy of the Operating Agreement, if the owner is a limited
liability company;
      (22)    A copy of the Partnership Agreement, if the owner is a
partnership;
      (23)    Specification of the days of the week and the hours of the day
during which the licensed activity will be conducted.
   (c)    Safety Service Director. The Safety Service Director shall, within
ten (10) business days of the receipt of the written application referenced in
Section
781.08(b), either issue such license or deny such license.
   (d)    Appeal to Board of Zoning Appeals. In the event of the denial of the
issuance of such a license, the applicant shall be notified of such denial, and
the specific reasons therefore, in writing. Such notice shall be mailed or
delivered to the applicant at the address specified in the application. The
applicant shall be given a reasonable notice of the date, time and place of the
hearing to appeal such denial, by filing a written notice of appeal and the fee
associated therewith with the Board of Zoning Appeals. Thereafter, the
applicant shall have not less than ten (10) days notice of the date, time and
place of the hearing. The appeal shall be heard by the Board of Zoning Appeals,
which, after hearing, shall confirm or deny the determination made by the
Safety Service Director.
   (e)    Appeal to Court. The decision of Board of Zoning Appeals may be
appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to Ohio Revised Code
Section 2506.
   (f)    License Renewal. Each computerized sweepstakes device license and
sweepstakes terminal café license must be annually renewed. At the time of
renewal, a statement shall be filed with the Safety Director that the
information listed on the original for the license is still complete, accurate
and truthful to the best knowledge of all applicants, or a statement shall be
filed with the Safety Director listing each and every item of information which
has changed since the original application. The Safety Director shall determine
whether to accept such statement and issue the license requested, or he may
determine to enforce the procedure required for an original license.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.09  DENIAL OF SWEEPSTAKES TERMINAL CAFÉ LICENSE.
   No sweepstakes terminal café license shall be issued or renewed for any
business or premises where any of the following facts or circumstances exist:
   (a)    Any of the owners or operators have been convicted within the last
five (5) years of any felony.
   (b)    Any of the owners or operators have been convicted within the past
five (5) years of any misdemeanor involving the operation of a sweepstakes
terminal café business, or involving physical violence, gambling activities,
controlled substances, alcoholic beverages, or crimes involving minors.
   (c)    The premises does not specifically designate at least thirty (30)
gross square feet of floor area for each amusement device to be located upon
the premises, excluding areas used for other principal uses.
   (d)    The premises does not provide a minimum of one (1) parking space for
every ONE (1) computerized sweepstake devices.
   (e)    The premises is located within one Thousand (1,000) feet of any
school, playground, public park, liquor establisment, cash loan business, or
another sweepstakes café, or within five hundred (500) feet of any church.
   (f)    The premises or operation thereof would be in violation of any
provision of the Building Code, Zoning Code, Fire Code of the City or any other
pertinent provisions of local, state or federal law.
   (g)    The applicant made a false statement as to a material matter upon the
application or in a hearing concerning the license.
   (h)    The application failed to provide all of the required information.
   (i)    The premises are prohibited from having interior access to a liquor
establishment.
   (j)    The terms and conditions under this chapter and all other applicable
ordinances and statutes have not been complied with.
      (Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.10  CONDITIONS AND REGULATIONS.
   n addition to any other condition or regulation contained in this chapter,
other provisions of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Alliance, or in Ohio
Revised Code or Ohio Administrative Code, the following conditions and
regulations shall be applicable to and shall govern and control the license of
a sweepstakes terminal café: (Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
   (a)    Each licensee shall at all times open each and every public or semi-
public portion of the premises for inspection by the Police Department and
other City Departments for the purpose of enforcing any provisions of this
Chapter. The interior of the main premises must be easily and readily viewable
from the exterior through at least one main window without obstruction,
blackout or other shading.
      (Ord. 13-13. Passed 5-6-13.)
   (b)    Each licensee shall have present on the premises at all times when
the premises are open to the public at least one adult operator who has not
been convicted of any crime referenced in Section 781.09(a). (Ord. 32-12.
Passed 4-2-12.)
   (c)    No such licensee shall open the premises for business except between
the following hours (local time) on the following days:
      (1)   9:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. during all days.
         (Ord. 13-13. Passed 5-6-13.)
   (d)   No licensee shall allow living quarters to exist with direct entry to
the premises.
   (e)   No such licensee shall allow any person, other than an owner or
operator over the age of eighteen (18) years, who shall be readily
identifiable, to be in control of premises.
   (f)   The licensee shall ensure that the operator is regularly situated in a
place upon the premises from which he or she has an unobstructed view of the
entire portion of the premises devoted to the operation of computerized
sweepstakes device.
   (g)    No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be permitted in
a sweepstakes terminal café.
   (h)    All sweepstakes rules and odds of winning shall be posted in a
conspicuous place at the premises and displayed on the computerized sweepstakes
device at the start of each game and/or activity.
   (i)    Each licensee shall operate the sweepstakes terminal café business in
compliance with all pertinent Federal Trade Commission rules and regulations.
   (j)    Every premises or a sweepstakes terminal café shall provide notice on
the main entry door, at the cash register, and at each computerized sweepstakes
device terminal, which shall appear clearly and conspicuously in bold-face type
of the minimum size of 14 point fount at the register and device terminal and
72 point fount at the main entry door in substantially the following form:
      (1)    No alcohol, beer or intoxicating liquor permitted.
      (2)    No purchase necessary to participate in this Sweepstakes Café.
   (k)   All Computerized sweepstakes devices upon the premises of a
sweepstakes terminal café shall be located thereon in conformity with the floor
plan filed with the application for the license. The floor plan shall ensure
the following:
      (1)    Non-impairment of ingress or egress to the premises;
      (2)    Non-interference with free and unfettered passage through the
premises;
      (3)    Allowance of a minimum of thirty (30) square feet of floor area
for each amusement device excluding areas used for other principal uses;
      (4)    Allowance of a minimum unobstructed area of three (3) feet on
either side of each amusement device where persons may use, watch or wait to
use such amusement device;
      (5)    A clear and complete view of the interior of the premises
immediately upon entry.
   (l)    Delineated areas for said café shall be clearly marked.
   (m)    The Licensee shall be responsible for submitting a documented
statement containing any and all winnings from each computerized sweepstake
device. Said statement shall be provided to the Tax Department on or before the
fifteenth of the following month. (Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.11 PROHIBITED CONDUCT AND CONDITIONS IN SWEEPSTAKES TERMINAL CAFÉ.
   (a)    No licensee of a sweepstakes terminal café, directly or indirectly,
or by a servant, agent or employee shall permit or fail to take active steps to
eliminate the activities specified in this section from occurring upon the
premises. All such licensees shall have a duty to diligently pursue enforcement
of this section. The actions of the operator and the failure to take action by
the operator shall be imputed to the licensees. No such licensee shall:
      (1)    Permit any disorderly conduct upon the premises;
      (2)    Permit an alcoholic beverage to be used, possessed, sold or
consumed on the premises;
      (3)    Permit gambling in any form or the possession or use of gambling
paraphernalia upon the premises;
      (4)    Permit the possession or use of any unlawful drug, narcotic or
controlled substance upon the premises;
      (5)    Permit the premises or the activity conducted thereon to become a
public nuisance to the surrounding environment;
      (6)    Permit the walkways serving the premises to become obstructed in
any manner so that pedestrian traffic is hindered;
      (7)    Permit any computerized sweepstakes device thereon to be operated
at any time the premises is not open for business, or permit the entrance to be
locked at any time that the premises is open for business;
      (8)    Permit any computerized sweepstakes device to be offered to the
public for operation unless fully safe and operable;   
      (9)    Permit the premises to be open for business without displaying the
license in a conspicuous place upon the premises;
      (10)    Permit the operation of any unlicensed computerized sweepstakes
device upon the premises; and
      (11)    Permit any violation of any federal, state or local law or
regulation upon the premises. (Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.12 POSSESSION OF ALCOHOL, BEER OR INTOXICATING LIQUOR IN SWEEPSTAKES CAFÉ
PROHIBITED.
   Possession of alcohol, beer or intoxicating liquor within the premises of a
sweepstakes terminal café shall constitute a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.13 LICENSE EXPIRATION, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   (a)    Expiration. Any sweepstakes terminal café license issued under this
chapter shall expire upon the transfer or sale of a majority interest in the
business, or the discontinuation of the business for a continuous period of
thirty (30) days. Any computerized sweepstakes device license issued under this
chapter shall expire upon the transfer or sale of such computerized sweepstakes
device.
   (b) Suspension and Revocation. All licenses issued under this chapter shall
be recommended to be suspended or revoked by the Safety Service Director upon
finding of the occurrence of any of the following events:
      (1)    A false statement by any licensee as to a material matter made in
an application for license or in a hearing concerning the license;
      (2)    Conviction of any licensee for any crime referenced in Section
781.09(a); two (2) convictions within one (1) year period of any licensee or
operator for a violation of the provisions of this chapter.
   (c)    Hearing. The suspension or revocation of any license under this
chapter shall not occur without a hearing before the Board of Zoning Appeals.
The licensee shall be given a reasonable notice of the date, time and place of
the hearing to suspend or revoke said license, which shall set forth the date,
time and place of the hearing and the specific reasons for such suspension or
revocation.
   (d)    Appeal.  The decision of Board of Zoning Appeal may be appealed to a
court of competent jurisdiction under Ohio Revised Code Section 2506.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.14  LICENSE FEES.
   (a)    Computerized Sweepstakes Devices. The fee for each computerized
sweepstakes device license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per device, per month.
   (b)    Sweepstakes Terminal Café.  The fee for a sweepstakes terminal café
shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year.
   (c)    Replacement License. The fee for a replacement license shall be
twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
   (d)    Filed with Application. The license fee referenced in Section 761.13
(b) shall be filed with the application for license.
   (e)    Return of Fee. In the event an application is denied under this
chapter, the license fee referenced in Section 761.13(b) shall be returned to
the applicant. In the event any license is suspended or revoked under this
chapter, no portion of the license fee referenced in Section 761.13(b) shall be
returned to the owner.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.15  EQUAL OPPORTUNITY.
   No person shall be denied any license under this chapter in the City of
Alliance based on race, color, creed, sex, religious belief or national origin.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
781.99 PENALTY.
   Unless otherwise provided herein whoever violates any of the provisions of
this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. A separate offense
shall be deemed to have been committed each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.
(Ord. 32-12. Passed 4-2-12.)
CHAPTER 791
Vacant Property Registry
791.01   Adoption; purpose.
791.02   Applicability.
791.03   Definitions.
791.04   Owner required to act; enforcement authority.
791.05   Registration required and penalty.
791.06   Additional enforcement provisions.
791.07   Appeals.
791.08   Miscellaneous.
   CROSS REFERENCES
Property Maintenance Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1369
791.01  ADOPTION; PURPOSE.
   (a)   The purpose of this Chapter is to establish a vacant property
registration program and to further regulate the maintenance of properties
which are in the foreclosure process, abandoned or vacant. This Chapter is
intended to reduce and prevent neighborhood blight, to avoid the creation and
continuance of public nuisances, to ameliorate conditions that threaten the
public health, safety and welfare, to promote neighborhood stability and
occupancy by preserving the condition and appearance of residential properties
and the worth and activity of commercial and industrial properties, and to
maintain property values and assessments.
   (b)   There is hereby adopted, then, for the aforementioned purposes and for
the purpose of providing a means of identifying the owner and/or responsible
entities of vacant and/or abandoned properties within the corporate limits of
the City of Alliance, Ohio having complete contact information on record for
these properties and responsible parties, a registration and maintenance
requirement for vacant and/or abandoned properties.
   (c)   Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to waive, relieve or
otherwise excuse an owner of property from compliance with all applicable
codes, ordinances, statutes or laws and the owner shall at all times remain
responsible and liable therefore. Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to
prevent the enforcement of other provisions of the Codified Ordinances of the
City of Alliance, Ohio or the Ohio Revised Code; and nothing in this Chapter
shall be construed to relieve an owner or interested party from duties imposed
pursuant to any regulatory code, ordinance, statute, or law of the City of
Alliance, Ohio or State of Ohio.
(Ord. 81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)
791.02 APPLICABILITY.
   This Chapter shall be applicable to all residential, commercial, and
industrial structures located within the corporate limits of the City of
Alliance, Ohio.
(Ord. 81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)
791.03  DEFINITIONS.
    As used in this section:
   (a)   “Abandoned" means a structure that is unoccupied as the result of the
relinquishment of possession or control by an owner or other person with the
right of possession or control of the structure, a mortgagor or the mortgagor's
assigns whether or not the mortgagor or mortgagor's assigns have relinquished
equity and title. A structure may be deemed abandoned when there is evidence of
conditions, taken separately or as a whole, that would lead a reasonable person
to conclude that the property was abandoned, including, but not limited to,
evidence of overgrown or dead vegetation, accumulation of newspapers,
circulars, flyers, mail, past due utility notices, or other means of notice by
publication, the accumulation of junk, litter, trash, or debris, absence of
windows or window treatments, absence of furnishings and personal items,
statements of neighbors, delivery agents or similarly situated persons that the
property is abandoned.
   (b)   "Safety Service Director" means the Safety Service Director of the
City of Alliance, Ohio or his or her designee.
   (c)   "Codes" means the Codified Ordinances of the City of Alliance, Ohio or
those adopted by said Codified Ordinances.
   (d)   "Inspector" means a person employed by or under contract to City of
Alliance, Ohio to perform inspections to determine compliance with Codes and to
order corrective measures and/or initiate administrative, civil, or criminal
proceedings.
   (e)   "Vacant" means a structure that is not lawfully occupied or that
otherwise qualifies as "Abandoned" under this Section. Multi-family residential
structures shall be considered vacant when substantially all of the dwelling
units are not lawfully occupied or that otherwise qualifies as "Abandoned"
under this Section. Commercial structures shall be considered vacant when all
commercial activity has ceased at the site or that otherwise qualifies as
"Abandoned" under this Section. Multi-tenant commercial structures shall be
considered vacant when substantially all of the units are not lawfully occupied
or engaging in commercial activity, or that otherwise qualifies as "Abandoned"
under this Section. Industrial structures shall be considered abandoned when
all industrial or manufacturing activity has ceased at the site or that
otherwise qualifies as "Abandoned" under this Section. Multi-tenant industrial
structures shall be considered vacant when substantially all of the units are
not lawfully occupied or engaging in industrial or manufacturing activity, or
that otherwise qualifies as "Abandoned" under this Section. In determining
whether a structure is vacant, it is also relevant to consider, among other
factors, the percentage of the overall square footage of the building or floor
not in use to the occupied space; the condition and value of any items in the
structure and the presence of rental or for sale signs on the property.
A property that is temporarily unoccupied and is in the process of being
lawfully renovated under proper and unexpired permits shall not be considered
vacant.
A property that is listed for sale with a licensed realtor under a fully
executed listing agreement shall not be considered vacant for the first six
months of the listing agreement under which the property was first listed for
sale. Such property shall be considered vacant for purposes of this Section
upon the expiration of the first six month period for which it is first listed
for sale or upon a subsequent re-listing with the same or a different licensed
realtor. Unoccupied property listed as "For Sale by Owner" shall be considered
vacant for purposes of this Section.
   (f)   "Owner" means the registered owner of a property, any person who holds
legal or equitable title to the property, is a mortgagee, a vendee-in-
possession, assignee of rents, executor, trustee, lessee, agent or any other
person, firm or corporation that is directly or indirectly in control of a
property. The Owner of a property in default or for which a foreclosure action
is pending or for which a judgment in foreclosure has been issued shall include
the mortgagee, the successor in interest to the mortgagee, the lender or
servicing company and any agent acting for the mortgagee, its successors, or a
lender or servicing company. Under this definition, there may be more than one
"Owner" of a property for purposes of this Chapter.
   (g)   "Secure" means a secure covering shall be placed over all doors and
windows which are within fifteen feet of the exterior grade, consisting of one-
half inch thick plywood attached to the framing of all such doors and windows
by wood screws of a minimum length of one and one-half inches, placed twelve
inches on center. Such plywood shall be painted with a minimum of two coats of
oil-based exterior paint. In order to be considered secure, a property must
also be in compliance with all requirements of the Sebring Codified Ordinances.
      (Ord. 81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)
791.04  OWNER REQUIRED TO ACT; ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY.
   (a)   The Owner of any structure that has become vacant as defined above
shall, within thirty (30) days after the structure first becomes vacant, or
within thirty (30) days of receiving notice that a structure is vacant, or
within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this Chapter, whichever is
later, file a registration statement for each such structure with the Manager
or his or her designee on forms provided for such purposes. Any Owner of a
property which files a foreclosure action involving said property, or for which
a foreclosure action is pending, or a judgment of foreclosure has been issued
shall, in addition to all other requirements of this Section, provide a cash
bond acceptable to the Safety Service Director or his designee, in the sum of
not less than Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00), to secure the continued
maintenance of the property throughout its vacancy and compensate the City of
Alliance for any expenses incurred in inspecting, securing, repairing, marking
and/or making such building safe by any legal means including, but not limited
to, demolition. A portion of said bond in an amount to be determined by the
Safety Service Director (but not to exceed ten percent (10%) per annum of the
principal amount of the bond posted) shall be retained by the City of Alliance
as an administrative fee to fund an account for expenses related to
administering this program.
      (1)    The registration statement shall remain valid for one year from
the date of registration. The registering party shall be required to annually
renew the registration as long as the structure remains vacant and shall pay an
annual registration fee as described below:
         For residential structures
         •    First year vacant: one hundred dollars ($100.00)
         •    Second year vacant: two hundred dollars (S200.00)
         •    Third year vacant: four hundred dollars ($400.00)
         •    Fourth year vacant eight hundred dollars ($800.00)
         •    Fifth year vacant and beyond: One thousand six hundred dollars
($1,600.00)
         For commercial and industrial structures
         •    First year vacant: four hundred dollars ($400.00)
         •    Second year vacant: eight hundred dollars ($800.00)
         •    Third year vacant One thousand six hundred dollars ($1,600.00)
         •    Fourth year vacant: Three thousand two hundred dollars
($3,200.00)
         •    Fifth year vacant and beyond: Six thousand four hundred dollars
($6,400.00)
         However, all religious, educational, benevolent or charitable
associations, all governmental agencies shall be exempt from the payment of the
annual registration fee. The registering party shall not be entitled to a
refund of all or any part of the registration fee should the structure no
longer be deemed vacant during the annual registration period.
      (2)   The owner shall notify the Safety Service Director or his or her
designee within twenty (20) days of any change in the registration information
by filing an amended statement on a form provided for such purposes. The
registration statement shall be deemed prima facie proof the statements therein
contained in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding
instituted by the City of Alliance, Ohio against the owner of the structure. An
owner shall be liable under this section for failing to register a vacant
structure, failing to pay an appropriate annual registration fee, or failing to
timely update any change in registration.
         (Ord. 048-25. Passed 8-4-25.)
   (b)   (1)   In addition to other information required by the Safety Service
Director, the registration statement shall include the name, street address and
telephone number of a natural person twenty-one years of age or older,
designated by the owner as the authorized agent for receiving notices of code
violations and for receiving process in any court proceeding or administrative
enforcement proceeding on behalf of such owner in connection with the
enforcement of this Chapter. This person must maintain an office in Stark or
Mahoning Counties, Ohio, or must actually reside within Stark or Mahoning
Counties, Ohio. An owner who is a natural person and who meets the requirements
of this subsection as to location of residence or office may designate him- or
herself as agent.
      (2)   By designating an authorized agent under the provisions of this
subsection the owner is consenting to receive any and all notices of code
violations concerning the registered building and all process in any court
proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding brought to enforce code
provisions concerning the registered structure by service of the notice or
process on the authorized agent. Any owner who has designated an authorized
agent under the provisions of this subsection shall be deemed to consent to the
continuation of the agent's designation for the purposes of this subsection
until the owner notifies the Safety Service Director or his or her designee in
writing of a change of authorized agent or until the owner files a new annual
registration statement. An owner shall be liable under this Section for failing
to register an authorized agent.
   (c)   The owner of any vacant structure shall, within fifteen (15) days of
registering a vacant structure, cause a physical inspection of the structure to
be made and Secure the structure in accordance with this Chapter, and shall
cause photographs to be taken of the property that accurately portrays the
condition of the structure. Photographs shall be dated and preserved by owner.
An owner shall be liable under this Section for failing to inspect the property
or structure or for failing to maintain the inspection photographs as required
by this Section.
   (d)   Any owner who fails to register a vacant structure under the
provisions of this subsection shall further be deemed to consent to receive, by
posting at the structure, any and all notices of code violations and all
process in an administrative proceeding brought to enforce code provisions
concerning the structure and premises.
   (e)   The Safety Service Director may issue rules and regulations for the
administration of this Section. These rules may designate board-up materials
and methods which must be used when securing a structure beyond the standards
provided so that the boarding is reasonably incapable of being removed by
trespassers or others acting without the owner's consent.
(Ord. 81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)
791.05 REGISTRATION REQUIRED AND PENALTY.
   (a)   The Owner of any vacant structure shall file a registration statement
for each such structure with the Safety Service Director or his or her designee
on forms provided for such purposes. Any such registration statement shall be
deemed prima facie proof of the statements therein contained in any
administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the
City against the owner or owners of the structure.
   (b)   The owner of any vacant structure who fails to file a registration
statement for each such structure within the timeframes established by this
Chapter or who fails to update a change in registration information within the
timeframes established by this Chapter shall be subject to a fifty dollar
($50.00) per day administrative penalty with a maximum penalty of one thousand
dollars ($1,000).
   (c)   Notwithstanding any other language in this Chapter and unless
otherwise specified, any person who violates any provision of this section or
of the rules and regulations issued hereunder and fails to maintain the
property according to the Codes shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor
and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each offense. Every day that a violation continues shall
constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)
791.06  ADDITIONAL ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Unless otherwise specifically provided, the owner, the owner's agent
for the purpose of managing, controlling or collecting rents, and any other
person managing or controlling a structure or premises in any part of which
there is a violation of the provisions of this code, shall be liable for any
violation therein, existing or occurring, or which may have existed or
occurred, at or during any time when such person is or was the person owning or
managing, controlling, or acting as agent in regard to said structure or
premises and is subject to injunctions, abatement orders or other remedial
orders.
   (b)   The liabilities and obligations hereunder imposed on an owner shall
attach to a trustee under a land trust holding title to such building,
structure or premises without the right of possession, management or control,
unless said trustee in a proceeding under said provisions of this code
discloses in a verified pleading or in an affidavit filed with the court, the
name and last known address of each person who was a beneficiary of the trust
at the time of the alleged violation and of each person, if any, who was then
acting as agent for the purpose of managing, controlling or collecting rents,
as the same may appear on the records of the trust.
   (c)   The liabilities and obligations imposed on an owner shall attach to
any financial institution, mortgage company, or any other person or entity with
or without an interest in the structure or premises who knowingly takes any
action in any judicial or administrative proceeding that is intended to delay
issuance or enforcement of any remedy for any violation of the Codes, provided
that with respect to fines such person shall be liable only for fines which
accrue on or after the date of such action and further provided that no
liability shall be imposed under this section for any action taken in any
proceeding, including a proceeding to foreclose on a lien, that does not delay
or prevent the prosecution of any action brought by the Municipality to enforce
the adopted Codes.
   (d)   In the event the City of Alliance, Ohio, due to lack of response of an
owner or agent, is required to take action, through its own efforts or via a
contract for such services, to abate a nuisance at a vacant property the owner
will be billed for the cost of the abatement to include all labor and materials
needed to correct the violation. Nuisance abatements shall include, but are not
be limited to, elimination of hazardous conditions, cutting of weeds and
overgrowth, securing and/or boarding of a structure, trash cleanup and disposal
and demolition.
(Ord. 81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)
791.07 APPEALS.
   Appeals from administrative actions shall be processed in accordance with
Ohio Revised Code, Section 2506 et seq.
(Ord. 81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)
791.08 MISCELLANEOUS.
   (a)   Severability. If any section, subsection, clauses, phrase or portion
of this section is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court
of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct
and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of
the remaining portion thereof.
   (b)   Savings Clause. The repeal or amendment herein shall not abrogate or
affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture
incurred, or any pending litigation or prosecution of any right established or
occurring prior to the effective date of this ordinance, as amended.    (Ord.
81-13. Passed 12-16-13.)

521.03
 
 
901.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed herein, unless otherwise provided.
   (a)    "Unimproved street" means a street without any surface improvement.
   (b)    "Improved street" means a street of added surface by stabilization
such as asphalt, oil or any bituminous application.
   (c)    "Paved street" means a street of brick surface laid on concrete,
sand, crushed slag or gravel, or a street constructed of sheet asphalt,
asphaltic concrete or a resurface of sheet asphalt or asphaltic concrete over
brick, or a street of entire concrete construction.
      (1963 Code §901.01)
901.02 PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   No person other than the proper duly authorized officers of the City shall
make any openings or excavations in any street or public ground of the City
without a permit to do so. Any such person desiring such permit shall file with
the Director of Public Safety and Service a written application setting forth
the location, kind, number, size of openings or excavations to be made and the
time during which such openings or excavations are to remain open.
(1963 Code §901.02)
901.03 PERMIT ISSUANCE AND FEE.
   The Director of Public Safety and Service or his designee shall, upon the
filing of an application as provided for in the preceding section, investigate
the same, and if it is deemed necessary, issue a permit to the person filing
the application authorizing such person to make the openings or excavations at
the places, for the purpose, and at the time set forth in the application. Such
person shall first pay to the Director of Public Safety and Service or his
designee a permit fee as set forth in Chapter
117 - Fees for the opening or excavation.
(Ord. 125-05. Passed 3-5-07.)
901.04 EXCAVATIONS BY PUBLIC UTILITIES; PERMIT; INSPECTION AND FEE; DEPOSITS.
   Any gas, railway, telephone, telegraph, electric light or like company which
is occupying and using the streets or public grounds of the City under a valid
franchise, before making any opening or excavation in any of the streets or
public grounds of the City shall first file an application for a permit as
provided for in Sections
901.02 and
901.03. If such permit is granted, the Director of Public Safety and Service
shall direct one of the regularly appointed inspectors of the City to supervise
and inspect the making of such opening or excavation and the refilling or
repaving of the same. Such work must be done in the manner directed by the
inspector. The company to whom the permit authorizing the making of such
opening or excavation was granted, shall pay to the City the cost of such
supervision and inspection, which cost shall be the prevailing rate for each
City Inspector, for each inspector so employed from the time such opening or
excavation is started until it is permanently completed. Each of the companies
shall maintain a deposit with the Director of Public Safety and Service at all
times of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) to be used by the Director
in payment of the inspection provided for in this section. The Director of
Public Safety and Service shall issue no permits to any of the companies named
herein which fail to maintain such deposits.
(Ord. 122-68. Passed 12-2-68.)
901.05 SIDE SUPPORTS FOR EXCAVATIONS OVER FIVE FEET.
   No person shall excavate any sewer or trench within the corporate limits of
the City to a greater depth than five feet unless the sides of such trench or
sewer excavated are supported by proper cribbing strong enough to prevent the
earth from caving or falling in.
   In all contracts on behalf of the City for the construction of sewers or
trenches, it shall be stipulated that excavations to a greater depth than five
feet must be supported by proper cribbing. (1963 Code §901.05)
901.06 SIGNAL LANTERNS.
   Every person making openings in any street or public ground of the City
under the provisions of this chapter shall place, keep and maintain at his
expense, at or near such opening or excavation, not less than two signal
lanterns and as many more as shall be necessary. Such person shall keep the
same lighted at all hours of the night so that the opening or excavation may be
seen by any person passing along or near such opening or excavation. The signal
lanterns shall be kept lighted every night from dusk until daylight, so long as
such opening or excavation remains open.
(1963 Code §901.06)
901.07 REFILLING EXCAVATIONS; RESTORING PAVEMENT.
   Any person making openings or excavations in any street or public grounds of
the City, except as provided in Section
901.04, shall immediately, upon having completed the work for which such
opening or excavation is made and under the direction of a City inspector,
refill such opening or excavation with an approved granular material in six
inch courses with each course being tamped in place with a mechanical
compactor. The Director of Public Safety and Service shall thereupon cause any
opening to be paved with asphalt and/or concrete. All back-fill work performed
by the person making the opening or excavation shall be done under the
direction of a City inspector.
(Ord. 96-81. Passed 12-21-81.)
901.08 PRICE SCHEDULE FOR REFILLING AND REPAVING.
   The Director of Public Safety and Service shall prepare a schedule of prices
for the placement of asphalt pavement placed under the provisions of this
chapter. Any person making openings or excavations shall pay to the City the
cost of the required inspection, which cost shall be based on the prevailing
hourly rate for each City inspector, except that the permit fee shall be
credited against the inspection costs.
(Ord. 14-81. Passed 3-16-81.)
901.09 CONTRACTED CITY PROJECTS EXCEPTED.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to persons making openings or
excavations within the corporate limits of the City for or under the provisions
of a valid contract entered into between them and the City, and for the purpose
of constructing sewers or other street improvements. (1963 Code §901.09)
901.10 NOTICE TO FIRE DEPARTMENT REQUIRED.
   No person shall dig any ditch or make any excavation, or cause any ditch to
be dug or excavation to be made, on any public street or other public place
without, before commencing to dig such ditch or make such excavation, first
notifying the Fire Department of his intention to dig such ditch or make such
excavation.
(1963 Code §901.11)
901.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any such violation shall constitute a separate
offense on each successive day continued.
CHAPTER 903
Street Improvements and Vacating Property
903.01    Policy for petitioned capital improvements.
903.02    Financing for resurfacing paved streets and oiling unpaved streets.
903.03    Costs of vacating public property.
903.04    Additional City financing for paving improvements.
903.05    Construction specifications.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to establish and care for streets - see Ohio R.C. 715.19, 717.01, 723.01
Vacating streets - see Ohio R.C. 723.04 et seq.

Compulsory service connections prior to paving - see Ohio R.C. 729.06, 743.23,
743.37
Street excavations - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
901
Paving alley crossings abutting street to be repaved - see S.U. & P.S.
905.08
Wires to be placed in underground conduits upon contemplated street paving -
see S.U. & P.S.
907.03
 
 
903.01 POLICY FOR PETITIONED CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS.
   When a petition subscribed by fifty percent in interest of the owners or
fifty percent of the foot frontage of property abutting upon any street, alley
or highway in the City, is regularly presented to Council for the purpose of
improvement of such street, alley or highway, such petition shall be honored in
the same manner as petitions heretofore submitted to Council, subject to the
provisions of Ohio R.C. 727.06, and any other statute relating to petitions for
capital improvement and assessment.
(Res. 49-62. Passed 5-7-62.)
903.02 FINANCING FOR RESURFACING PAVED STREETS AND OILING UNPAVED STREETS.
   Whenever a majority of persons owning property abutting a fully paved street
petition Council for the resurfacing of such street, the City shall pay fifty
percent of the cost of such improvement, which fifty percent shall include all
other statutory amounts required to be paid by the City.
   Whenever a majority of persons owning property abutting upon a street
petition Council for the oiling of such street, the City shall pay fifty
percent of the cost of such improvement, which fifty percent shall include all
other statutory amounts required to be paid by the City.
(Ord. 55-62. Passed 5-21-62.)
903.03 COSTS OF VACATING PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   On all vacations of streets, alleys or other public grounds, the owner or
owners of premises immediately abutting such vacated street, alley or other
public grounds shall pay into the General Fund of the City an amount per square
foot which is equal to the average tax value per square foot of the land which
immediately abuts the vacated portion upon both sides, together with the costs
of advertising and replatting. The average tax valuation shall be based on the
tax valuation appearing on the latest tax bill received from the County
Treasurer at the time the petition for vacation is filed with Council.
(Ord. 47-77. Passed 4-18-77.)
903.04 ADDITIONAL CITY FINANCING FOR PAVING IMPROVEMENTS.
   (a)    Council hereby establishes the policy that it will assume an
additional seven percent of the total cost beyond the two percent required by
Ohio R. C. 727.05 for full paving improvement projects which include grading,
draining, curbing and paving with seven-inch concrete surface or eight-inch
water-bound macadam base with a two and one-half inch asphaltic surface.
   (b)    Such additional seven percent contribution in addition to the two
percent statutory requirement as set forth in Ohio R. C. 727.05, shall be
further limited in any given calendar year by the total sum allocated to street
improvements in the Master Capital Improvement Ordinance in that calendar year.
   (c)    The payment of the additional seven percent of the total cost beyond
the statutory two percent shall be further limited by proper petitions
presented to Council, on the date established by Council in any given calendar
year, as provided by Section
903.01 hereof. Such petitions requesting full paving projects set forth in
subsection (a) hereof shall be received in the office of the Clerk of Council
before the date established by Council as the date that Council will consider
petitions entitled to the additional seven percent contribution.
(Ord. 14-69. Passed 2-17-69.)
903.05 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS.
   There is hereby adopted by the City, a standard set of drawings and
specifications for the construction of streets, sanitary and storm sewers and
water mains as established by the City Engineer and copies of which are on file
in the office of the City Engineer and the office of the Clerk of Council for
the use and examination by the public. Such standards are adopted for the
purpose of regulating the construction of streets, sewers and water lines and
necessary appurtenances thereto within the City and environs.
(Ord. 12-73. Passed 3-19-73.)
CHAPTER 905
Sidewalk and Driveway Construction
905.01   Sidewalk permit required.
905.02    Line and grade establishment.   
905.03    Completion notice; inspection; certificate.   
905.04    Compliance with other provisions required.
905.05    Driveway permit required.
905.06    Construction specifications.
905.07    Removal of unused driveways; curb reconstruction.
905.08    Construction of public, private alley crossings.
905.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Construction or repair at owner's expense - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
Placing injurious material or obstructions in streets - see TRAF.
311.01
Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
521.03
Sidewalk obstructions - see GEN. OFF.
521.04
Duty to keep sidewalks in repair and clean - see GEN. OFF.
521.06
 
 
905.01 SIDEWALK PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall construct a sidewalk within the corporate limits of the City
until he has secured a permit from the City Engineer to do so.
(1963 Code §905.01)
905.02 LINE AND GRADE ESTABLISHMENT.
All sidewalks must be laid to the line and grade established by the City
Engineer.
(1963 Code §905.02)
905.03 COMPLETION NOTICE; INSPECTION; CERTIFICATE.
   Upon the completion of the construction of any sidewalk under the provisions
of this chapter, the property owner shall notify the City Engineer who shall
inspect the same. If such sidewalk is constructed according to the standard of
construction of sidewalks in the City and if all the provisions of this chapter
have been complied with, the City Engineer shall issue a certificate of
inspection approving such sidewalk.
(1963 Code §905.03)
905.04 COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER PROVISIONS REQUIRED.
   No certificate of inspection shall be issued by the City Engineer under the
provisions of Section
905.03 unless the property owner has complied with the provisions of these
Codified Ordinances and all other ordinances of the City which refer to the
construction of sidewalks.
(1963 Code §905.04)
905.05 DRIVEWAY PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall construct or improve, or cause to be constructed or
improved, ay driveway or driveway approach from a public street or thoroughfare
to private property without first having made application and received a permit
therefore from the City Engineer, which permit fee is set forth in Chapter
117 - Fees.
(Ord. 125-05. Passed 3-5-07.)
905.06 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS.
   The driveway or driveway approaches constructed or improved pursuant to a
permit issued as provided in Section
905.05 shall be constructed in accordance with the following specifications:
   (a)    Where there is a lawn strip between the curb and the paved portion of
the sidewalk, any inclined portion of the driveway or approach shall be
constructed in the lawn strip area only. The established grade of the paved
portion of the sidewalks shall not be changed in any manner.
   (b)    Where the paved portion of the sidewalk immediately adjoins the curb
and no lawn strip exists, the inclined portion of the driveway or approach
shall be constructed to extend upon the sidewalk and curb not in excess of
twenty percent of the combined width of the paved portion of such sidewalk and
curb, but in no event shall the inclined portion of such driveway or approach
exceed two feet. The established grade of the remaining part of the paved
portion of the sidewalk shall not be changed in any manner.
   (c)    Such driveway approaches or inclines and the space intervening
between the driveway approaches or inclines shall be of such width as, in the
opinion of the City Engineer, would be suitable under the circumstances of each
particular case. In no case shall it be lawful to construct any driveway
leading into the street through and across a circular curb already established
and put in place by the City.
   (d)    Each permit issued as provided in Section
905.05 shall stipulate the width of the driveway approaches or inclines, the
number to be installed and, if there is more than one driveway approach or
incline, the width of the space between the same.
      (1963 Code §905.06)
905.07 REMOVAL OF UNUSED DRIVEWAYS; CURB RECONSTRUCTION.
   Driveway approaches or inclines leading into a street which are not being
used as a driveway approach or incline, either through change of circumstances,
relocation of buildings or for any other reason, are hereby declared to be a
nuisance and shall be removed. A sidewalk and curb shall be constructed thereat
by the owner of the property abutting such sidewalk within thirty days of
receipt of notice from the City Engineer that such nuisance exists. Failure to
comply with such notice shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor, and failure to
comply in each five-day period thereafter shall be considered a separate
offense.
(1963 Code §905.07)
905.08 CONSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC, PRIVATE ALLEY CROSSINGS.
   All public or private alley crossings abutting any street or highway being
permanently improved by paving shall be constructed with the same material as
that with which the abutting street is being paved. All such public or private
alley crossings shall be constructed the full width of the alley and shall
extend from the inside lot line to the outside gutter line.
   All other public or private alley crossings not included in the terms of the
preceding paragraph shall be constructed of paving block, asphalt or cement and
shall be constructed the full width of the alley and shall extend from the
inside lot line to the outside gutter line.
   The Engineering Department is hereby instructed to set no grade stakes, nor
shall the Street Department accept any alley improvement that is not
constructed in conformity with this section. (1963 Code § 905.08)
905.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which an offense occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 907
Poles, Wires and Conduits
907.01    Permit to erect poles required.   
907.02    Painting, stenciling poles to show ownership.
907.03    Wires to be placed in underground conduits upon contemplated street
paving.
907.04    Notice to owner of wires.

CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate electrical wires and poles - see Ohio R.C. 715.27(B)
Excavations by public utilities - see S.U. & P.S.
901.04
 
 
907.01 PERMIT TO ERECT POLES REQUIRED.
   No public utility doing business in the City, or any of its officers, agents
or employees, shall place, or cause to be placed, service poles in any of the
streets of the City without having first obtained the written permission of the
Director of Public Safety and Service as to the relocation of poles already in
the streets as well as to the installation of new poles.
(1963 Code §907.01)
907.02 PAINTING, STENCILING POLES TO SHOW OWNERSHIP.
   All telephone and telegraph companies, electric light and power companies
and other persons erecting or maintaining poles upon the public streets,
sidewalks or other public places of the City shall paint or stencil such poles
with the name of the company, firm or person owning or operating such pole, in
a plain and legible manner. Such painting or stenciling shall be kept at all
times in such a condition that it can be plainly read.
(1963 Code §907.02)
907.03 WIRES TO BE PLACED IN UNDERGROUND CONDUITS UPON CONTEMPLATED STREET
PAVING.
   Any person having any system of wires supported by poles used in connection
with any telephone, telegraph, electric light or power service and located upon
any City street twenty feet or more in width, which street is about to be
paved, shall, within sixty days after receiving the notice as provided for in
Section
907.04, place all of such wires underground in proper conduits of approved
construction. Such conduits shall be laid without interfering with any water or
sewer system in the City.
(1963 Code §907.03)
907.04 NOTICE TO OWNER OF WIRES.
   The Director of Public Safety and Service shall, when any street mentioned
in Section
907.03 is about to be paved, notify in writing the local representative or
manager of such telephone, telegraph, electric light or power company owning
any wires or cables supported by poles upon the part of the street intended to
be paved, to place such wires in underground conduits as required by Section
907.03 within the time provided.
(1963 Code §907.04)
907.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which violation continues or occurs.
CHAPTER 909
Trees
909.01   Planting trees which obscure vision or cause damage.
909.02   Trimming trees required; height above pavement.
909.03   Failure to trim after notice; certification to County Auditor.
909.04   Removal of dead or dying trees.
909.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.20
      Assessments for tree planting or maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
      Shade Tree Commission - see ADM. Ch.
159
      Destruction of trees - see GEN. OFF.
541.06
909.01 PLANTING TREES WHICH OBSCURE VISION OR CAUSE DAMAGE.
   No person shall set out, plant or transplant any tree, shrub or other large
perennial plants which obscure vision, hinder traffic or cause damage to
streets, curbs, sidewalks or sewers, utilities and appurtenances, within any
public street, alley or highway, especially, but not limited to, that portion
of the street, alley or highway in the area between the street and the edge of
the sidewalk commonly known as the curb lawn.
(Ord. 51-62. Passed 6-4-62.)
909.02 TRIMMING TREES REQUIRED; HEIGHT ABOVE PAVEMENT.
   Every person who is the owner of or is an agent having the care of any
premises within the City which abut on any public street or highway shall trim
and keep trimmed all trees growing on such premises, or between the premises
and the edge of the sidewalk where branches of trees overhang any portion of
such street or highway, or overhang any part of the pavement or sidewalk of
that part of such street or highway so abutting upon such premises. Such trees
shall be trimmed and kept trimmed so that the lowest branch thereof shall be at
least eleven feet above the level of that part of such pavement, sidewalk,
street or highway so overhung by such branches.
(1963 Code §559.06)
909.03 FAILURE TO TRIM AFTER NOTICE; CERTIFICATION TO COUNTY AUDITOR.
   In the event the owner or his agent shall neglect or refuse to trim or keep
trimmed the branches of such trees as provided in Section
909.02, the City may, after ten days’ written notice to the owner or occupant
of such abutting property, cause such trees to be trimmed and charge the
expense thereof to such owner. Upon being unpaid, such amount shall be
certified by the proper City official to the County Auditor and the same shall
act as a lien upon the property of such owner and be collected as provided in
the case of special assessments. The notice herein provided may be served by
registered letter, addressed to the owner or occupant of such premises, by
mailing the same to the last known place of residence of such owner or
occupant.
(1963 Code §559.07)
909.04  REMOVAL OF DEAD OR DYING TREES.
      (a)    Every person who is the owner of or is an agent having the care of
any premises within the City shall remove or have removed all dead or dying
trees located in a street right of way or on private grounds which are
dangerous to users of streets or sidewalks, dangerous to public health and
safety, infected or infested by any parasite, insect or disease, or which
otherwise constitute a public nuisance and which removal is necessary to
safeguard the lives or property of other persons or to prevent the breeding or
scattering of any parasite, insect, pest or disease to other trees or plants.
   (b)   In the event the owner or his agent neglects or refuses to remove such
dead or dying trees, the City may, after ten days' written notice to the owner
or his agent, cause such trees to be removed and charge the expense to the
owner. Upon being unpaid, such amount shall be certified by the proper City
official to the County Auditor and the same shall act as a lien upon the
property of such owner and be collected as provided in the case of special
assessments.
   (c)   Proper service of the notice required by Section
909.04(b) shall be by personal service, residence service, or by registered
mail; provided, however, that such notice shall be deemed to be properly
served, if a copy thereof is sent by registered mail to the owner's or agent's
last known address. If any of the parties cannot be located, nor his address be
ascertained, the notice shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof
is placed in a conspicuous place on or about the premises affected by this
notice. If such notice is by registered mail, the ten-day period within which
such owner is required to comply with the order shall begin as of the date he
received such notice as evidenced by the return receipt. If certified mail
service is refused or unclaimed as evidenced by the return of such certified
mail with an endorsement showing such refusal or that the envelope was
unclaimed, the enforcing official shall reissue the notice by ordinary mail
retaining the certified mail envelope and endorsement as evidence of such
failure of certified mail service; and service of the notice shall be deemed
completed upon mailing of the ordinary mail notice. (Ord. 51-18. Passed 8-6-
18.)
909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
